requirement.description:
This section contains information on the system use cases, the HCI use cases are described in Section 1.1 of this document.  The system use cases incorporate the design of the Renaissance project, but do not have corresponding User Interfaces.  In many cases the system use cases support the HCI use cases.

ACTIVITY:  Management of Instrument Messages

 

 

[See attachment TTRM5878964358798210292.wmf]

 

Figure 1:  UC- Management of Instrument Messages

workflow-event.notes: System event generated by rule [Move to Draft] Actions: Enter [Auto Sort] event

requirement.description:
This activity outlines the processing of messages to and from the Instrument.  This processing is divided into two major groups, the processing of cassette loading messages and the processing of loaded cassette messages.  The loading cassette use cases describe the creation of a cassette.  The loaded cassette use cases describe the updating of cassette and isolates once created.  Two messages can be found in either branch based on workflow. They are Process Card Rejected Messages and Process Card Ejected Messages.

 

Summary of Loading Cassettes

 

There are 6 possible test messages in this branch.  They include:

  • Card Info, sent when a card is first scanned by the Instrument;
  • Card Info End, sent to indicate that all Card Info messages have been sent from a cassette;
  • Card Load, sent when the card is loaded into the carousel in the Instrument; Workstation uses the information from the message to update an existing test card record.
  • Card Rejected, sent when a card is not valid for placing in the Instrument carousel;
  • Card Load Failed, sent when a card could not be physically moved into the Instrument carousel.
  • Card Ejected, sent to the Workstation when a card is physically removed from the carousel.

    •  

    In normal processing, a cassette is initialized as soon as the first Card Info message is received from the cassette.  When the Card Info End message is received, the Workstation makes the cassette accessible to the user via the Renaissance application.

     

    Summary of Loaded Cassettes

     

    There are 3 possible test messages associated with this branch.  They include:

  • If a Card Data message is received, Workstation updates the associated test card record.  Workstation then analyzes the data appropriately (i.e. depending on the Card Product for the card it is from – ID or AST), and, if an isolate group has been defined for the card, finishes by attempting to analyze the isolate group (Analyze Isolate Data use case)  the card belongs.
  • Card Ejected message, sent to the Workstation when a card is physically removed from the carousel.
  • Card Rejected, sent when a card is not valid for placing in the Instrument carousel.

    •  

    Processing of other messages

     

    The Workstation software also reconciles a virtual cassette against the physical cassette when a Card Info End message is received by matching each card bar code recorded for the virtual cassette against the card bar code received in the card Info messages by slot number.  If they match, the isolate information from the virtual cassette slot is transferred to the physical cassette’s card record.  If the Workstation detects any reconciliation problems (i.e. non-matches), these are flagged and the cassette is made available for repair by means of the Post Entry view and the use case Setup Tests Post Entry.  (Note:  The Instrument performs an independent reconciliation process for virtual cassettes that are sent to the Instrument from the Workstation.)

     

    Of the various error messages received, most are simply logged.  Workstation terminates any card that has a Card Rejected message or Card Load Failed message.  Before the first Card Info message, the Instrument may send error messages with cassette and card information (fill failure, transfer failure, instrument reconciliation failed if a virtual cassette was set up beforehand).

     

     

    Summary of Information sent from the Instrument to the Workstation

     

    The majority of the information sent from the Instrument to the Workstation is either cassette or test centric.  A significant amount processing is needed for these messages because they involve the creation of cassettes or data analysis (ID or AST).  Some test messages include:   card Info, card info end, card Load, card data, etc..  For details, please  see the use case Process Test Messages.

     

    Raw data messages (card data)

  • These are RLU (relative light units; transmittance) readings from the wells on the cards.  Identification and Susceptibility analysis uses this information to determine the organism identification and the MIC of each antibiotic.  A majority of the information that flows from the Instrument to the Workstation will be these data messages.  A Lab Tech has no interest in these messages.  The Lab Tech cares about the results of the analysis of these messages.

    •  

    Instrument alarm conditions

  • These are messages sent to the Workstation to document an error condition in the Instrument.  For example, if the temperature in the incubator would become too high, an alarm would be sent to the Workstation alerting the Lab Tech that an error condition has occurred in the Instrument.  The Lab Tech has an interest in these messages.

    •  

    Documentation events

  • Per 21-CFR, the Instrument must document some processing events; for example, the time of a card fill or the time of a card load in the Instrument.  These messages would be sent to the Workstation for storage purposes only.  The Lab Tech will usually have no interest in these messages.  Another example of a processing event is that a card has been ejected from the Instrument.  If the Instrument is running at full capacity, the number of cards in the Instrument is important to the Lab Tech.  If the Instrument is not running at full capacity, this information is not of interest to the Lab Tech.  Based on Marketing information, the Instrument will not be running at full capacity in most labs.

    •  

     

    Summary of Information sent from the Workstation to the Instrument

     

    Workstation also sends messages to the Instrument.  However, the Workstation does not control the processing of cards on the Instrument; this is independent of the Workstation (Renaissance Software).  Card processing is under the control of firmware running on the Instrument.  If the Workstation-Instrument lose communication, cards are still processed on the Instrument.

     

    Virtual cassette definition (VITEK 2 Compact only)

  • The Lab Tech can create a “virtual cassette” on the Workstation.  This is a cassette with isolate information that has not been loaded into the Instrument.  The message is sent so the Instrument can do a reconciliation between the “virtual cassette definition” and the “real cassette definition” based on the cards that are scanned by the Instrument.

    •  

    Eject a card

  • This can be done at the request of the Lab Tech or as a result of analysis.  At any time after a card is loaded, the Lab Tech can instruct the Instrument to remove a card from the instruments carousel.  Also, if the results of analysis indicates a problem with a card, the analysis software running on the Workstation can request that a card be ejected from the Instrument.

    •  

    Well map

  • For both ID and AST card products, the Workstation will send card layouts to the Instrument.  For an AST card, the well map contains  which antibiotics are in what wells and how the Instrument (which optics) should be used to read that card.  An AST card is defined to the Workstation following the Maintain AST card Definition use case by a customer.  For an ID card, the well map contains  which biochemicals are in what wells and how the Instrument (which optics) should be used to read that card.

 

 

Instrument/Workstation Interface

 

 

  1. Significant changes from previous versions:

 

  • Instrument will not maintain any record of ‘terminated’ cards.  Instrument will instead ‘reject’ cards and let Workstation know.
  • This leads to a new Instrument message:  card rejected, which will be applied to any cards the Instrument doesn’t like, but only until they are loaded.  Once they are loaded, it’s up to the Workstation to request that a card be ejected.  The request can come from the application or from the user.
  • Instrument will only check carousel capacity at read time now, not at read time AND load time.  Cards that can’t be accommodated based on the capacity check at read time will be rejected (left in the cassette).

 

 

  1. Instrument/Workstation Interaction (NEW indicates change from existing Communications Spec)

When a cassette is filled, Instrument generates a Filler Event message (NEW), indicating “failed” or “succeeded” fill status.  During or after a fill, the Tech will have the option of resetting the instrument, and if he/she does so, the Instrument will generate a Transfer Aborted message (NEW).

 

After the cassette is successfully filled, the Tech has a limited time to transfer the filled cassette to the reader/loader window.  If the transfer is not made in time, Instrument generates a Transfer Timeout message (NEW).  The reader/loader stays enabled.  The Tech will have to reset the instrument (generating a Transfer Aborted message) to perform another fill cycle.  Note:  a Fill Failure and a Transfer Failure will result in Instrument prompting the Tech for the Cassette ID.

 

At read time, the cassette and each card is scanned.  Instrument then checks for available carousel space and reconciles its information against any matching virtual cassette information that may have been provided by the workstation:

 

 

  • If there isn’t enough space in the carousel for all the cards in the cassette, the cassette will be presented to the Tech for a short period to change the cassette contents.  After the allowed adjustment time, any card that exceeds the carousel capacity will generate a Card Rejected message, with reason “no space in Carousel” and be left in the cassette.
  • The Instrument will check to see if the Cassette ID points to a virtual cassette image that was downloaded from the Workstation.  If one is found, Instrument will reconcile each scanned card’s bar code and slot number against the information for the virtual cassette.  If there are any problems (missing, extra, unknown cards) Instrument will generate a message for documentation.  Note:  this is only for logging purposes;  Workstation will still do its own reconciliation.

    •  

    After reconciliation (if any), Instrument sends EITHER a Card Info message or a card rejected message (depending on the results of the scan) for each card in the cassette.  After the last card info message is sent, Instrument sends a Card Info End message (NEW).  The Card Info end message will trigger the Workstation to make the cassette visible; if the cassette was defined as a virtual cassette, the workstation will transfer the virtual cassette information and make the Cassette ID available for reuse.

     

    At load time, the Instrument sends a card load message for each card as it is loaded into the carousel.  Instrument failures between scan and load result in the Instrument generating a card load failed message (NEW) for each affected card, with a parameter indicating the reason for the failure:

     

  • If a seal failure occurs, all cards in the cassette will have card load failed message generated, with reason of “Seal Failure”.
  • A general Instrument failure will also impact all cards, with reason “Instrument Failure.”
  • If there’s a jam while cards are being loaded into the cassette, each card not loaded will generate a card load failed message, with reason “load jam”.

 

Whenever the Workstation requests that a card be ejected, the status of the card is changed to “eject pending”.  As soon as the card has been ejected, the Instrument sends a card Ejected message and reason (max incubation, ejected from host, malfunction).  When the message is received, Workstation changes the card status to “ejected”.  Note:  Card eject requests from the Workstation for a cassette being loaded will be delayed by the Workstation until a card load or card load failed message has been sent for the card that is to be ejected.

 

 

A description of the messages included here can be found in Host Communication Protocol (HCP] Specification.  Please see that specification for further details.

Monitor Instrument Messages

Primary actor

Instrument (generalization of VITEK 2 Compact (CARD), or VITEK 2)

Goal

The Workstation can receive a variety of messages from the Instrument.  The purpose of this use case is to determine the message type, validate the message, and then route for proper processing.  

Preconditions

Communication between Instrument and Workstation Established

Assumptions

None

Description

Step

Action

[REN:PRD:180]

This use case begins when the Workstation receives a message from the Instrument.

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Message not recognized

 

2.0

Workstation validates the Instrument Message and executes use case Process Test Messages.

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Event message received (type E, W, or A)

Alternate Flow A5:  Instrument status received

The use case ends.

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:161

Communication failure

A1.1

See Instrument / Workstation Communications Design Specification [R7] (use case ends) [REN:PRD:211] [REN:PRD:212] [REN:PRD:352]

A2

REN:ESPEC:162

Message not recognized

A2.1

See Instrument / Workstation Communications Design Specification [R7] (use case ends) [REN:PRD:211] [REN:PRD:212] [REN:PRD:352]

A3

REN:ESPEC:163

Event Message received (type E, W, or A)

A3.1

Workstation persists and display the message information. [REN:PRD:211] [REN:PRD:212] [REN:PRD:352]

 

A3.1.1   The type A message is for an audit event.  Information is stored in the application audit trail.  Refer to the Search Audit Trail use case for details.  

A3.1.2    Types E and W are for error and warning events.  Information is stored in the Instrument alarm history.  Refer to the Instrument Status and Alarm use cases for details.

A3.1.3   If FMLA-IT communication is enabled and the message type is E, the Workstation notifies FMLA-IT of the error.

 

 

A3.2

Use case ends

A4

REN:ESPEC:164

Event Message received (type D)

A4.1

Workstation logs message text. [REN:PRD:211] [REN:PRD:212] [REN:PRD:352]

 

A4.1.1    The type D message is for a diagnostic event.  Information is stored in the one of the application logs, usually Core.

 

 

A4.2

Use case ends

A5

REN:ESPEC:165

Instrument status received

A5.1

Workstation updates Instrument and carousel information, such as type of Instrument connected, available carousel positions, etc.  Refer to the Instrument Status and Alarm use cases for details, Monthly QA Report, and Instrument Status Report use cases. [REN:PRD:211] [REN:PRD:212] [REN:PRD:352]

 

A5.1.1   Workstation receives a carousel status message (caro status).  A type U message is used by the Workstation to create/update the Current Instrument status report.  A and type R message is used by the Workstation to create/update the Instrument QA Monthly Report.

A5.1.2   Workstation receives an Instrument information message (inst info). Workstation uses this information to create/update instrument information and information  for the Instrument Status report.

A5.1.3   Workstation receives an Instrument status message (instStatus (VITEK 2 only) and instStatusCompact (Compact only).  Workstation uses this information to create/update information for the Instrument Status report.

 

 

A5.2

Use case ends

A6

REN:ESPEC:166

REN:ESPEC:555

Card ejected

A6.1

Steps moved to the card ejected use case

 

 

 

 

 

 

A7

REN:ESPEC:552

Message not valid (added per DR-3522)

A7.1

Workstation determines that the message received from the Instrument is not valid. [REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:211] [REN:PRD:212] [REN:PRD:352]

 

Developer and tester note:  an example of an invalid packet is a "null" (empty) Card Data message.  This was the issue surrounding DR-3522.

 

 

A7.2

Workstation removes the invalid message from the instrument message queue and saves it to another location on the hard drive. This allows the application to continue to process new instrument messages in the queue.

 

A7.3

Workstation records this event in the application troubleshooting log file for later investigation by support personnel.  Information includes the date/time the invalid message was detected and a brief description of the problem.  

 

Developer and tester note:  in the case of an empty packet, a description like:  Unable to marshall the following message…  is acceptable.

 

A7.4

Use case ends

 

 

 

Special Requirements

None

requirement.description:
Name

Process Test Messages

Primary actor

Instrument – VITEK 2 or VITEK 2 Compact instrument

Other actors

Workstation – Renaissance Software

Goal

This use case manages all test messages received by the Workstation from the Instrument related to cassettes and cards.  Workstation determines if the message is for a loading cassette or for a loaded cassette.

 

Preconditions
  • Instrument test messages are validated.  Any invalid messages generate exceptions in the Workstation, causing any details to be logged.

 

Assumptions
  • Happy path:  workstation receives a message for a loading cassette.
  • The happy path assumption is that the Instrument will always send a card info before a card load failed or a card load.
  • For the same card bar code, the Instrument will not send both a card load and a card load failed message.

 

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:167

[REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:174]

[REN:PRD:175] [REN:PRD:177]

[REN:PRD:178] [REN:PRD:179]

[REN:PRD:180]

[REN:PRD:629]

[REN:PRD:628]

1.0

This use case starts when the Workstation receives a test message from the Instrument.

 

Developer/Tester note:  Test messages include card info, card rejected, card info end, card load, card load failed, card ejected, and card data.  Card load failed is another valid test message and is handled as an alternate flow in the Process Card Load use case.

 

2.0

Workstation determines that a cassette needs to be created or a loading cassette needs to be updated with data.  

 

2.1   Workstation executes the Process Loading Cassette use case.

 

Developer/Tester note:  Test messages for a loading cassette include card info, card rejected, card info end, card ejected, card load and card load failed.  

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Workstation receives a test message for a cassette that already been loaded.

 

 

3.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions

A cassette is either created or updated.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:558

Workstation receives a test message for a cassette that is already loaded.

A1.1

Workstation executes the Process Loaded Cassette use case. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

Developer/Tester note:  Test messages for a loaded cassette include card data, card rejected and card ejected.

 

A1.2

Use case ends

 

 

 

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:559

 

Expected Order of Instrument Test Messages

 

Normal processing:  no errors detected in the processing of cards

  1. One or more Card Info messages
  2. One Card Info End message
  3. One or more Card Load message
  4. More than one Card Data messages

 

Normal processing:  errors detected in the processing of a cards

 

  1. One or more Card Rejected messages (can be sent at any time)
  2. One or more Card Load Failed message (sent instead of card Load message)

 

Other issues related to messages:

 

  1. Any message can be missing
  2. Messages can be sent out of order
  3. After a power failure, messages could be sent again without a retransmit flag.

 

Rule:  The Workstation should attempt to process messages that are sent out of order, determined to be missing, or duplicated without retransmit flag .  Any condition mentioned above that cannot be processed as described in these use cases is treated as an exception (i.e. logged, and the message is otherwise ignored in standard processing).  If analysis cannot proceed, then the Instrument is instructed to eject the card.

 

[REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

requirement.description:
Name

Process Loading Cassette

Primary actor

Instrument – VITEK 2, VITEK 2 XL or VITEK 2 Compact instrument

Other actors

Workstation – Renaissance Software

Goal

This use case manages all test messages received by the Workstation from the Instrument related to a new or existing loading cassette.

Preconditions
  • Workstation receives a loading cassette test message (e.g. card info, card rejected, card info end, card ejected, card load or card load failed).

Assumptions
  • Card load messages will be received after all card info messages have been received (i.e. card info end message sent)
  • Any exceptions to the receipt order described is treated as an exception (i.e. logged, but otherwise ignored in standard processing)
  • The ‘happy path’ in this use case assumes creating a cassette.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:560

[REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:174]

[REN:PRD:175] [REN:PRD:177]

[REN:PRD:178] [REN:PRD:179]

[REN:PRD:180]

[REN:PRD:629]

[REN:PRD:628]

 

1.0

This use case starts when the Workstation receives a card info message from the Instrument.  

 

1.1   For each card info message:  Workstation executes the Process Card Info Message use case.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Workstation receives card rejected message.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Workstation receives a card ejected message.

 

 

2.0

Instrument sends a card info end message.

 

2.1   Workstation executes the Process Card Info End Message use case.

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Workstation determines that a card info end message was not received as expected.

 

3.0

Instrument sends a card load or card load failed message.

 

3.1   For each card load or card load failed message:  Workstation executes the Process Card Load Message use case.

 

 

4.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions
  • A cassette exists in the Workstation with all associated card information in the correct slots.
  • A card exists for each card info and card rejected message received by the Workstation.
  • The resulting cassette is not in the loading state.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:561

Workstation receives card rejected message

A1.1

Workstation executes the Process Card Rejected Message use case. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

A1.2

Use case continues with step 1.0 in the main flow if additional messages are needed to be processed.  If no more messages are needed to be processed, the use case ends.

 

Developer and tester note:  branching back to step 1 was added to indicate that a cassette usually consists of multiple cards.  

A2 REN:ESPEC:562

Workstation receives a card ejected message.

A2.1

Workstation executes the Process Ejected Message use case. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

A2.2

Use case continues with step 1.0 in the main flow if additional messages are needed to be processed.  If no more messages are needed to be processed, the use case ends.

 

Developer and tester note:  branching back to step 1 was added to indicate that a cassette usually consists of multiple cards.  

 

 

 

A3

REN:ESPEC:553

Workstation determines that a card info end message was not received as expected.

A3.1

Workstation continues processing at step 3.0 of the main flow.  In essence, the Workstation is able to recover from a missing card info end message by processing other test messages which follow.  [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

Developer and tester note:  see the card info, card rejected, or card load use cases for details on how a missing card info end message is handled.

 

 

 

Special Requirements

None

requirement.description:
Name

Process Card Info Message

Primary actor

Instrument – VITEK 2, VITEK 2 XL or VITEK 2 Compact instrument

Other actors

Workstation – Renaissance Software

Goal

This use case manages the Workstation processing of a card info message from the Instrument.

 

Preconditions
  • Workstation receives a valid card info message from the Instrument.

Assumptions
  • card info messages will be received in cassette slot number order
  • card info end, card load, card load failed and card data messages will be received after all card info messages have been received
  • The ‘happy path’ in this use case assumes a Load and Go cassette.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:169

[REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:174]

[REN:PRD:175] [REN:PRD:177]

[REN:PRD:178] [REN:PRD:179]

[REN:PRD:180]

[REN:PRD:629]

[REN:PRD:628]

1.0

This use case starts when the Workstation receives a card info message from the Instrument.

 

2.0

Using information within the card info message, Workstation determines that this is a new card (i.e. the card has not be previously processed by the Workstation).

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Existing preliminary card found from a different cassette for given bar code.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Existing non-preliminary card found from a different cassette for given bar code.

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Existing preliminary card found from the same cassette for given bar code.

 

3.0

Workstation creates a card within the system and persists the following information from the card info message:

 

3.1   Card Bar Code

3.2   Card Bar Code Source (example:  Instrument, entered by user, etc.)

3.3   Cassette Slot Number in which the card is associated

 

 

4.0

Using the cassette ID and Instrument serial number (BCB number), Workstation finds one or more loading cassettes that match the information in the card info message.

 

4.1   Workstation selects the matching cassette based on  cassette ID and the cassette time.

 

Alternate Flow A4:  No matching cassettes found

 

 

5.0

Workstation adds the card to the cassette in the correct slot.

 

Alternate Flow A5:  A preliminary or non-preliminary card already exists in the same slot.

 

Alternate Flow A6:  A non-preliminary card (e.g. card rejected, card deleted, card eject pending, etc.)  already exists in the same slot.

 

 

 

 

 

6.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions
  • A cassette exists in the Workstation containing the new card information in the correct slot.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:563

Existing preliminary card found from a different cassette for given bar code.

A1.1

Workstation terminates the existing card and generates an instrument alarm as described in the Instrument Status and Alarms activity.  Workstation records the reason as duplicate barcode. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

Developer and tester note:  in a future release we may want to inform the Instrument to eject the terminated card.

 

A1.2

Use case ends.  

A2

REN:ESPEC:564

Existing non-preliminary card found from the same cassette for given bar code.

A2.1

Workstation generates an instrument alarm as described in the Instrument Status and Alarms activity.  Workstation records the reason as duplicate barcode. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

A2.2

Use case ends.  

A3

REN:ESPEC:???

 

A3.1

Workstation logs a warning. [non-retransmit only]

 

Per a review held on 4/11/2006 with the development and testing teams, this case is covered by alternate flows in other use cases.  This alternate flow is now redundant and can be removed.

 

A3.2

Use case ends.  

A4

REN:ESPEC:565

No matching cassettes found

A4.1

Workstation creates a cassette within the system and persists the following information from the card info message: [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

A4.1.1   Instrument Serial Number (BCB number)

A4.1.2   Cassette ID

A4.1.3   Cassette load date/time (Date & Time cassette loaded in the instrument reader)

A4.1.4   Card Dilution Mode (VITEK 2 only; blank for VITEK 2 Compact)

 

 

A4.2

Use case resumes at step 4.0 in the main flow.

A5

REN:ESPEC:566

A preliminary or non-preliminary card already exists in the same slot.

A5.1

Workstation executes Process Card Info End Message use case. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

Developer and tester note:  this step was added in order to handle a missing card info end message, DR-2775.  In essence, the "stuck loading cassette" is completed and the processing of the new cassette continues.

 

A5.2

Workstation creates a cassette within the system and persists the following information from the card info message:

 

A5.1.1   Instrument Serial Number (BCB number)

A5.1.2   Cassette ID

A5.1.3   Cassette load date and time (Date & Time cassette loaded in the instrument reader)

A5.1.4   Card Dilution Mode (VITEK 2 only; blank for VITEK 2 Compact)

 

 

A5.3

Workstation adds the card to the new cassette.

 

A5.4

Workstation sets an instrument alarm as described in the Instrument Status and Alarms activity.  Workstation records the reason as slot contention.

 

Developer and tester note:  slot contention describes the error in which the Workstation attempts to place a card in a cassette slot that already contains a card bar code.

 

Specific information recorded for this event includes:

 

A5.4.1   Cassette ID of the "loading" cassette

A5.4.2   Date and time the "loading" cassette was presented to the Instrument

A5.4..3   The card bar code for each card Info message received for the "loading" cassette.

A5.4..4   A description of the problem (Instrument communication for this cassette was not complete…missing an important message).

 

 

A5.5

Use case ends.  

A6

REN:ESPEC:567

 

A6.1

Removed from use case on 4/17/2006 following developer and tester review.

 

 

 

Special Requirements

None

requirement.description:
Name

Process Card Rejected Message

Primary actor

Instrument – VITEK 2, VITEK 2 XL or VITEK 2 Compact instrument

Other actors

Workstation – Renaissance Software

Goal

This use case manages the Workstation processing of a card rejected message from the Instrument.

Preconditions
  • Workstation receives a valid card rejected message from the Instrument.

Assumptions
  • Card ejected messages can be received at any time.  This includes during cassette loading, at the request of the Instrument, and following the request of as user to eject a card.
  • The ‘happy path’ in this use case assumes a Load and Go cassette.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:168

[REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:174]

[REN:PRD:175] [REN:PRD:177]

[REN:PRD:178] [REN:PRD:179]

[REN:PRD:180]

[REN:PRD:629]

[REN:PRD:628]

1.0

This use case starts when the Workstation receives a card rejected message from the Instrument.

 

2.0

Using information within the card rejected message, Workstation determines that this is a new card (i.e. the card has not be previously processed by the Workstation).

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Existing preliminary card found with given bar code.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Existing non-preliminary card found with given bar code.

Using the cassette ID and Instrument serial number (BCB number), Workstation finds one or more loading cassettes that match the information in the card rejected message.

Alternate Flow A3:  No matching cassette found

 

 

 

6.0

Workstation adds the card to the cassette in the correct slot.

If enabled in general configuration, Workstation updated the card usage information.

Branching Action

A3.1

Workstation creates a cassette within the system and persists the following information from the card reject message: [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

A4.4

Workstation sets an instrument alarm as described in the Instrument Status and Alarms activity.  Workstation records the reason as slot contention.

 

Developer and tester note:  slot contention describes the error in which the Workstation attempts to place a card in a cassette slot that already contains a card bar code.

 

Specific information recorded for this event includes:

 

A4.4.1   Cassette ID of the "loading" cassette

A4.4.2   Date and time the "loading" cassette was presented to the Instrument

A4.4..3   The card bar code for each card Info message received for the "loading" cassette.

A4.4..4   A description of the problem (Instrument communication for this cassette was not complete…missing an important message).

 

 

A4.5

Use case ends.  

 

 

 

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:572
  1. Rejected Cards

These error conditions will be identified by messages from the instrument to the workstation indicating the reason for card rejection.  They require user acknowledgement or repair (e.g. changes to isolate groupings if there was a virtual cassette) in Setup Test Post Entry.  Instrument would also send Cassette ID, cassette slot number, card bar code, date, time for each rejected card.  Rejected cards would be visible in Post Entry View for cassette, including card status and reason.

Examples of reasons include:

 

 

  • Instrument error:  Seal Failure

    • All cards in cassette will be rejected.  Instrument will send Cassette ID and card information for all cards.

  • Instrument error:  instrument not ready at load time.  (see Seal Failure, above)
  • Not enough space in carousel at load time

    • Only not-loaded cards will be rejected

  • Some cards in cassette exceeded allowable time limit between fill and load.

    • Only unloaded cards will be rejected

  • Expired Card in Reader (will be rejected)
  • Unknown card definition at Reader (card will be rejected).
  • SCS reconciliation error (VITEK 2 only)

[REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Process Card Info End Message
requirement.description:
Name

Process Card Info End Message

Primary actor

Instrument – VITEK 2, VITEK 2 XL or VITEK 2 Compact instrument

Other actors

Workstation – Renaissance Software

Goal

This use case manages the Workstation processing of a card info end message from the Instrument.

Preconditions
  • Workstation receives a valid card info end message from the Instrument.

Assumptions
  • a card info end message will be received after all card info messages have been received
  • Message submitted was not from an SCS cassette.
  • The ‘happy path’ in this use case assumes a Load and Go cassette.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:170

[REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:174]

[REN:PRD:175] [REN:PRD:177]

[REN:PRD:178] [REN:PRD:179]

[REN:PRD:180]

[REN:PRD:629]

[REN:PRD:628]

 

1.0

This use case starts when the Workstation receives a card info end message.

 

Developer and  tester note:   The processing of other messages may also cause the Workstation to execute this use case.  In all cases, a card info end message from the Instrument is not required to execute the functionality described here.

 

2.0

Using the cassette ID and Instrument serial number (BCB number), Workstation finds one or more loading cassettes that match the information in the card info message.

 

2.1   Workstation selects the matching cassette based on  cassette ID and the cassette time.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  No matching cassettes found

 

 

3.0

Workstation determines that the cassette ID contained in the message matches the cassette ID from a defined virtual cassette.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Virtual cassette not found for loaded cassette.

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Message is from an SCS cassette

 

4.0

Workstation reconciles each card bar code from the virtual cassette against the scanned bar codes from the loaded cassette (see Special Requirements for details).

 

4.1   For each matching bar code, Workstation transfers isolate information from virtual cassette to loaded cassette.

4.2   For each mismatch identified, the Workstation flags the card and identifies the problem (for example, wrong card, missing card, and extra card).

 

5.0

Workstation completes  the process of reconciliation.  Steps include:

 

5.1   Deletes the corresponding Virtual Cassette definition on the Workstation

5.2   Notify all attached Instruments to delete the corresponding Virtual Cassette definition.

5.3   If there are no reconciliation errors, make the cassette available in Post Entry View (see use case Setup Tests Post-Entry for details) in read-only mode.

5.4   If there are any reconciliation problems or rejected cards, Workstation will NOT make the cassette’s isolates available in Isolate/Bench/Tech View. The cassette will only be available in Post Entry View for any corrections that can be made. See use case Setup Tests Post Entry use case  for details.

5.5    If there are no reconciliation problems or rejected cards, Workstation makes all isolates available in Isolate/Bench/Tech View.

 

6.0

If 21 CFR 11 is enabled, Workstation records the currently logged on user ID as the Setup Technologist.

 

Rule: If no user was logged onto the Workstation when the card info end was received, the cassette is marked incomplete and the Setup Tech is '???'. Added for DR-3799.

 

7.0

If enabled in general configuration, Workstation updated the card usage information.

 

8.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions
  • A load and go cassette is available for editing.
  • The isolates in a virtual cassette, without any reconciliation problems, are displayed in isolate view and the cassette is no longer loading.
  • The isolates in a virtual cassette, with reconciliation problems, are displayed in Setup test post entry view and are available for editing.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:573

No matching cassettes found

A1.1

Workstation documents this condition in one of the support logs maintained by the application.

[REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

A1.2

Use case ends.

A2

REN:ESPEC:171

Virtual cassette not found for this physical cassette.

A2.1

If 21 CFR 11 is enabled, Workstation records the currently logged on user ID as the Setup Technologist. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

Rule: If no user was logged onto the Workstation when the card info end was received, the cassette is marked incomplete and the Setup Tech is '???'. Added for DR-3799.

 

A2.2

Use case ends.

A3

REN:ESPEC:574

Message is from an SCS cassette

A3.1

Workstation executes use cases associated with Manage SCS cassette for VITEK 2 activity. [REN:PRD:77] [REN:PRD:78] [REN:PRD:79]

 

A3.2

Use case ends

 

 

 

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:575

Virtual Cassette Reconciliation

There are 3 conditions which need to be detected in reconciling the physical cassette against the virtual cassette.

  • Missing Card:  a slot in the physical cassette should contain a card but doesn’t.
  • Extra Card:  a slot in the physical cassette should not contain a card but does.
  • Wrong Card:  a slot in the physical cassette contains a card with a bar code that is different from the bar code identified in the virtual cassette.

 

[REN:PRD:535] [REN:PRD:93]

requirement.description:
Name

Process Card Ejected Message

Primary actor

Instrument – VITEK 2, VITEK 2 XL or VITEK 2 Compact instrument

Other actors

Workstation – Renaissance Software

Goal

This use case manages the Workstation processing of a card ejected message from the Instrument.

Preconditions
  • Workstation receives a valid card ejected message from the Instrument.

Assumptions
  • Card ejected messages can be received at any time.  This includes during cassette loading, at the request of the Instrument, and following the request of as user to eject a card.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:555

REN:ESPEC:166

[REN:PRD:173] [REN:PRD:174]

[REN:PRD:175] [REN:PRD:177]

[REN:PRD:178] [REN:PRD:179]

[REN:PRD:180]

[REN:PRD:629]

[REN:PRD:628]

1.0

This use case starts when the Workstation receives a card ejected message from the Instrument.

 

2.0

Workstation updates the cards for each isolate with the fact that the card has

been ejected from the Instrument and the reason. Reasons include:

 

2.1 Max incubation

2.2 Request from host (i.e. user has ejected the card)

2.3 Instrument malfunction

 

Developer and tester note: in the case of an Instrument malfunction, the

Instrument will generate an alarm. The error code will be either 274 or 275

depending on the cause. This alarm will be handled the same way as other

alarms as outlined in View and Maintain Alarms use case.

 

Developer and tester note: unless the reason codes are handled correctly  by terminating an isolate with an ejected card, cards that are ejected as a result of an Instrument malfunction remain "preliminary" forever. There is no indication to the user in either cassette view or isolate view that processing has stopped for the isolate.

 

Rule:  The Workstation will instruct the Instrument to eject a card if card data message is received before a card info or card load message.

 

Rule:  The Workstation will instruct the Instrument to eject a card if card load message is received before a card info.

 

 

 

3.0

Workstation notifies ID and AST analysis that the card has been ejected.  Some special processing is needed in order to inform the user that no more data is coming for this card.  This applies to QC cards as well as non-QC cards.

 

  1. If the card ejected message indicates that no more raw data readings will be sent from the Instrument, and the card status is preliminary, then set card status to terminated.
    1. Otherwise, take no action.

 

Developer and tester note:  card ejected message from the Instrument use the following reason codes:

 

L’ – Reading limit reached. (Compact only)

‘R’ - ejectCard request from host OR requested from DML. (Compact only)

‘M’ - Instrument malfunction OR wellmap changed. (Compact only)

‘X’ – Miscellaneous. (Compact only)

‘l’ – Ejected due to max incubation (VITEK 2 only)

‘m’ – Ejected due to malfunction (VITEK 2 only)

‘r’ – Ejected due to  workstation request (VITEK 2 only)

‘x’ – Ejected due to carousel cleaning or miscellaneous (VITEK 2 only)

 

These codes could be used to determine if no more raw data readings are coming.  Refer to the VITEK 2 / VITEK 2 COMPACT Instrument / Workstation Communications Protocol for more details.

 

 

4.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions
  • The card is marked ejected.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

N/A

N/A

N/A

A1

A1.1

None

 

 

 

Special Requirements

None

requirement.description:
Name

Analyze Isolate Data

Primary actor

None (abstract use case)

Goal

This use case is used by other use cases to interpret test results for a whole isolate group after any of the cards in the isolate group have been changed or re-analyzed.

Preconditions
  • Workstation knows about the test (cardInfo and cardLoad messages processed successfully)
  • Analysis has completed for all cards in the isolate group.

Assumptions
  • For patient results, if an isolate group contains an ID card, Workstation applies the organism identification and any shared results from the identification card (for example: beta lactamase) to the isolate group when the group is created.  If an isolate group does not contain an identification card, the organism identification and any entered results are created and maintained at the isolate level separately from this use case.  See use cases Maintain Virtual Cassette, Setup Tests Post-Entry and View and Maintain Test Results for details.
  • AES is responsible for antibiotic interpretations based on the user-selected interpretation standard.
  • Workstation can differentiate a QC isolate from a patient/product isolate.

Trigger

Card analysis is initiated (new raw data is received from the instrument, or a user change that impacts isolate state or analysis.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:174

1.0

Workstation determines that all cards in the isolate group have completed analysis.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Analysis not complete for one or more cards in the isolate group.

 

Alternate Flow A4: Analysis fails (reanalysis or instrument reading) because of a user change.

 

 

2.0

Workstation determines the isolate group is associated with a patient/product.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Isolate is QC and contains only an ID card.

Alternate Flow A3   Isolate is QC and contains only an AST card.

 

 

3.0

If SRF is enabled and test is identification, Workstation completes SRF analysis by following Analyze SRF ID Data use case. [REN:PRD:348]

 

3.5

Workstation determines if the isolate should be flagged as a duplicate isolate.  If yes, the Workstation visually indicates that the isolate is qualified duplicate.  If no, the Workstation visually indicates the isolate state based on the state diagrams in the Modify Isolate Group use case.

 

4.0

Workstation:

 

 

4.1   Records the isolate status as ‘final’.

 

 

4.2   Workstation analyzes isolate data following included use case Apply Advanced Reporting Rule to Isolate.

 

 

4.3   Sends isolate results to validation (AES) following included use case Send Isolate Data to AES use case.

 

Rule:  If the organism associated with the isolate is a slashline or organism group not claimed by AES, then the Workstation must send to AES individual organisms that comprise the slashline or organism group.  This is needed so expert can complete analysis.  (Added per CR-188 on 5/8/2003)

 

Rule:  Isolate may have missing required offline tests in order to complete AES analysis.  In this case, AES will expertise antibiotics that are not dependent on the missing test.

 

 

4.4   Workstation analyzes isolate data following included use case Apply Advanced Reporting Rule to Isolate.

 

 

4.5   Workstation determines that “Suppress MIC from Chart Report” in the case of a therapeutic correction, or biologic correction with a therapeutic correction, or both are enabled in AST Configuration, and one or more antibiotics in the isolate is impacted.  (Note:  This information is returned by AES.) [REN:PRD:682] [REN:PRD:684] [REN:PRD:717]

 

  1. Workstation documents this information for each MIC in the isolate.  In this case, special processing is required in isolate view, lab report, and BCI.

4.5.2   Otherwise, no action is taken.

 

 

4.6   If enabled, automatically print a laboratory report for the isolate or QC isolate group. [REN:PRD:172] [REN:PRD:329]

 

Rule:  a lab report is to be automatically printed only once after card analysis completes.

 

(Added per DR-1022 on 10/23/2003)

Developer note:  if the user would like additional lab reports printed after "reanalysis" or isolate changes that call reanalysis, the user would be required to print the reports manually.  The exception would be following a "review" or "approve".  See the Review Results and Approve Results use case for additional information related to printing of reports.

 

 

4.7   If MBS enabled, transfer isolate information. (TBD)

 

Note:  This step is a placeholder.  At first, MBS was considered no different than an LIS in terms of data transfers.  Perry introduced the concept that MBS would get data as soon as card analysis completes.  Until this is resolved by further investigation into MBS, this step serves as a placeholder. Do we transfer isolate information that has not bee "reviewed" or "reviewed/approved"?

 

(Removed per CR-555 on 5/20/2003.  Observa 2 (MBS) is treated like an LIS per the Change Control Board).

 

 

4.8   If 21 CFR 11 enabled, Workstation creates an image of the laboratory report. [REN:PRD:348] [REN:PRD:422]

 

 

4.9   Workstation transfers isolate information to Data Management Systems following included use case Send Data to LIS.  Conditions include the following:

 

4.9.1   Does not contain any 'qualified / qualified duplicate results'

4.9.2   Does not need to be 'reviewed' or 'reviewed/approved'

4.9.3   Data management enabled for automatic transfer, then transfer to data management systems configured in BCI Link.

[REN:PRD:122] [REN:PRD:172]

 

Rule:  an isolate is to be automatically sent to Data Management Systems only once after card analysis completes.

 

Updated per DR-1736 on 12/15/2003

 

Developer note:  if the user would like isolates sent to LIS after "reanalysis" or isolate changes that call reanalysis, the user would be required to send the isolates manually.  The exception would be following a "review" or "approve".  See the Review Results and Approve Results use case for additional information related to sending isolates.

 

Developer Note:  "Isolate Information" consists of patient, specimen, isolate, and test information for any given isolate. Some examples of patient information include patient name and patient hospital number.  Some examples of specimen information include specimen type and specimen source.  Some examples of isolate information include laboratory ID number and isolate number.  Some examples of test information include card type, drugs, MIC values, and interpretations.  Information that is not included:  biochemicals and biochemical results.

 

For details, please refer to the Bi-directional Computer Interface Specification [R5] for details.

 

5.0

The use case ends.

post-conditions

Isolate management functions complete

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:175

Analysis not complete for one or more cards in the isolate group.

A1.1

Use case ends.

A2

REN:ESPEC:176

Isolate is QC and contains only an ID card

A2.1

Workstation compares expected organism identification with calculated organism identification and flags any discrepancies.

Note:  Workstation knows that E. coli ATCC29215 is the same as E. coli.

 

Removed for 05.01 Streamline QC.

 

A2.2

For each biochemical, Workstation compares expected biochemical results with calculated biochemical results and flags any discrepancies.  Expected biochemical results are:  "+", "-", or "v".  The "v" is used to indicated a variable reaction.  A variable expected biochemical result will match either a "+" or "-" calculated biochemical result.

 

Added per DR-271 on 4/15/2003.

 

Rule:  QC Weak positive biochemical reactions and QC weak negative biochemical reactions are converted to either positive or negative reactions for comparison to expected ranges.  This rule applies to the calculated biochemical reactions.

 

Added per CR-382 on 9/27/2003

 

A2.3

If enabled, Workstation automatically prints a QC Lab report.

 

A2.4

Workstation transfers isolate results to QC cumulative workspace. (Removed per CR-370 on 5/20/2003)

 

Rule:  If QC isolate needs to be "approved" or "reviewed/approved", do not transfer to QC Cumulative workspace.

 

Note:  the QC isolate will be transferred to the QC cumulative workspace as part of the processing in Review QC Results and/or Approve QC Results use case.

 

A2.5

If 21 CFR 11 enabled, creates an image of the QC Laboratory report.

 

A2.6

Use case ends

A3

REN:ESPEC:177

Isolate is QC and contains only an AST card

A3.1

For each antibiotic, Workstation compares expected MIC results with calculated MIC results and flags any discrepancies.

 

A3.2

If enabled, Workstation automatically prints a QC Lab report.

 

A3.3

Workstation transfers isolate results to QC cumulative workspace. (Removed per CR-370 on 5/20/2003)

 

Rule:  If QC isolate needs to be "approved" or "reviewed/approved", do not transfer to QC Cumulative workspace.

 

Note:  the QC isolate will be transferred to the QC cumulative workspace as part of the processing in Review QC Results and/or Approve QC Results use case.

 

A3.4

If 21 CFR 11 enabled, creates an image of the QC Laboratory report.

 

A3.5

Use case ends.

A4

REN:ESPEC:720

Analysis fails (reanalysis or instrument reading) because of a user change.

A4.1

Instrument messages are not dropped as a result of a user change. System completes the user change and will retry to make the instrument change. [REN:PRD:700]

 

A4.2

System tries up to 10 times.

 

A4.3

If all 10 tries fail, workstation generates an alarm indicating that analysis failed and why.

 

A4.4

Use case ends.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Special Requirements

requirement.description:
Name

Analyze AST Data

Goal

This Use Case analyzes incremental instrument raw data readings from an AST card, with the intention of producing biologic results – a Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) for each antibiotic on the card against the organism the card was inoculated with.  It is invoked from various use cases, such as Setup Tests Post-Entry, Select and Move a Test, and Process Test Messages.

 

The analysis process is cyclic.  With the receipt of each message of raw data, containing the results from the whole card and so multiple antibiotics, the Workstation may attempt to generate a biologic result.  If test data indicates that the card was not inoculated properly, or the terminating threshold is reached, the test is terminated and no further analysis is attempted.

Preconditions
  • System knows about the test (cardInfo and cardLoad messages received and processed)
  • Composition of the card is known (Card Definition is standard).
  • A new reading has been received, or the user has requested re-analysis.

Primary actor

None (abstract use case)

Assumptions
  • Multiple antibiotic results can be generated per test.
  • One antibiotic result can terminate without affecting the entire test.
  • Invalid organism-drug combinations are not possible, since they are controlled when an isolate group is set up (for example, in use case Setup Tests Post-Entry)
  • Rules are established to extend incubation time.
  • Special processing of AST cards that contain cefuroxime may be necessary.  See Special Requirements section for details.  (Added per CR-292 on 5/23/2003)
  • As of 07.01, AST analysis supports both a 64 well card or a 104 well card.

 

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:178

1.0

Workstation confirms that the card contains results that are acceptable for analysis as evidenced from growth in the positive control (PC) well, by calculating the following analysis parameters for the PC well using the antibiotic specific threshold for the PC well defined in the Analysis Specification:

 

For Discriminant Analysis (DA), these parameters are used:

  • % change
  • slope
  • area under the curve
  • MSLPAR
  • SLPAR
  • Max percent change
  • Max slope [REN:PRD:184]

 

For Growth Pattern Analysis (GPA), these parameters are used:  

 

  • Rank
  • Pattern
  • PC Slope
  • Potential
  • Lag Time
  • Relative Slope
  • Incubation Time Matrix [REN:PRD:710] [REN:PRD:711]

 

This step is applicable to both 64 well and 104 well AST cards.

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Insufficient readings to calculate parameters

 

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Insufficient growth in PC well

 

Alternate Flow A14:  AST Card contains only a PC well (i.e. no antibiotics)

 

2.0

If card is acceptable, Workstation screens readings for missed readings (sequence gaps) and chooses which data to use for analysis. [REN:PRD:181]

 

(Note:  This is based on rules in the Susceptibility Data Analysis Specification.  For example, if there is a time difference greater than 40 minutes between consecutive readings, the reading following the gap may be ignored in calculating analysis parameters.  See the Analysis Specification for details.)

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A4:  Insufficient data left to analyze after screening raw data

 

3.0

For each well on the AST card, Workstation uses the wavelength specified for the antibiotic in the well (see Analysis Specification) to analyze the contents as follows:

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A5:  Offline tests or organism missing for antibiotic (Updated per CR-201 on 10/19/2002)

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A6:  Maximum incubation time reached with no determination

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A7:  Org/Drug combination not claimed (i.e. disclaimed)

 

Alternate Flow A13:  Organism identification is either "low discrimination", "slashline", or "unidentified"

 

 

 

3.1   System determines which algorithm parameters to use as specified in the Analysis Specification.  Options include:

   3.1.1 GPA parameters

   3.1.2 DA parameters (Original AST parameters) [REN:PRD:710] [REN:PRD:711]

 

See Special Requirements for a high level description of GPA.

 

 

3.2   Verifies data quality is acceptable

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A8:  Initial inoculation data value too low

 

 

3.3   Eliminates data spikes using algorithm specific threshold as defined in the Analysis Specification.

 

 

3.4   Calculates analysis parameters for either Discriminant Analysis (DA) or Growth Pattern Analysis (GPA), depending on which analysis method indicated by the knowledge base. [REN:PRD:710] [REN:PRD:711]

 

   3.4.1 – Discriminant Analysis (DA):

  • % change
  • slope
  • area under the curve
  • MSLPAR
  • SLPAR
  • Max percent change
  • Max slope

 

   3.4.2 – Growth Pattern Analysis (GPA)

 

  • Rank
  • Pattern
  • PC Slope
  • Potential
  • Lag Time
  • Relative Slope
  • Incubation Time Matrix

 

Alternate Flow A12:  Dead time not exceeded for well

 

 

 

3.5   Applies incubation time extension rules and then verifies that sufficient time has passed to call an MIC for the antibiotic.

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A9:  Insufficient incubation time

 

 

3.6   Determines the biologic result (MIC) for this antibiotic from the expected parameter set that most closely matches computed parameters (see Analysis Specification).

 

 

3.7   Records time of call for the antibiotic, biologic result (MIC), AST analysis message, and antibiotic status as ‘final’. [REN:PRD:674]

 

4.0

When all antibiotics in the card have an antibiotic status of 'final', 'abandoned, or 'disclaimed', Workstation records the test status itself as ‘final’ and instructs the Instrument to eject the card if there are no antibiotics /tests that are disclaimed.

 

Rule:  If one or more antibiotics are terminated, but not all are terminated, then the card is still considered final. (Added to match reference method implementation on CODD on 1/20/2004.)

 

Rule:   If a card contains one or more antibiotics/tests that are disclaimed, analysis completes when the last antibiotic/test becomes final.  However, the card is not ejected from the Instrument until max incubation.  Added per DR-3761 and DR-4302.

 

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A10:  Any antibiotic has a status of ‘preliminary’

 

 

Alternate Flow A11:  All antibiotics are ‘terminated’

 

Updated on 10/19/2002 per CR-201.

 

Disclaimed= organism not claimed for AST analysis

Abandoned= missing required offline test or organism

 

5.0

This Use Case ends.

post-conditions
  • Results generated:  MIC per antibiotic analyzed, or results terminated.
  • Test status updated.
  • Results of analysis recorded (biologic result).

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:655

(Added per CR-292 on 5/23/2003)

 

 

GPA parameters differ from original AST parameters:

   GPA uses growth characteristics to determine a pattern, which is used to look

   up the MIC result. [REN:PRD:710] [REN:PRD:711]

Business Rules:

The following business rules apply to all of the above examples.

  1. Overall rule includes:  
    1. If there is an Instrument malfunction as documented in the cardEject message, and as a result one or more antibiotics terminate, then the card status is set to “terminated”.
  2. Supporting rules include:
    1. If the current card status is “final”, system performs reanalysis, and there is no change in current antibiotic status, then the card status remains “final”.
    2. If the current card status is “terminated”, system performs reanalysis, and there is no change in current antibiotic status, then the card status remains “terminated”.
    3. If the card status is “final” and additional raw data readings are received from the Instrument with a cardEject message indicating a malfunction and an antibiotic now terminates, then the card status becomes “terminated”.  This can occur if the system is set to eject at max incubation and an Instrument malfunction occurs after the card is “final”.
    4. In the case of NDU from 03.01 to 04.01, the system assumes that the card has reached its final state without Instrument malfunction.  Since the reason for the cardEject message was not persisted in 0.301, the assumption made is that all cards completed without an Instrument error.

requirement.description:
Name

Analyze ID Data

Primary actor

None (abstract use case)

Goal

This Use Case analyzes incremental instrument raw data readings from an ID card, with the intention of producing biologic results – an organism identification.  It is invoked from various use cases, such as Setup Tests Post-Entry, Select and Move a Test, and Process Test Messages.

 

The analysis process is cyclic, but modal.  With the receipt of each message of raw data, the Workstation may attempt to generate a biologic result:

  • If the analysis mode is ‘kinetic’, analysis is performed each time a reading is received, once initial development quality and incubation time thresholds are achieved, until an interpretation is made or a maximum incubation time is exceeded.
  • If the analysis mode is end-point, analysis is performed at a specific point in the incubation process, but only after an initial quality threshold is reached.

In either case, if test data indicates that the card was not inoculated properly, or the maximum incubation time is reached, the test is terminated and no further analysis is attempted.

Preconditions
  • System has received cardInfo and cardLoad messages successfully for test data.
  • Composition of the card is known (Card Definition is standard)
  • Workstation has received new test information from a single ID card or re-analysis has been requested for an ID card; i.e. a specific ID card is available to be analyzed.

Assumptions
  • Usually one identification result is generated per test
  • Evaluate biopattern uses all available well data.
  • Not all wells are required to generate an organism identification
  • No rules established to extend incubation time.
  • A card can already be positive by the time it is first read by the Instrument (i.e. ‘early incubation positive’)
  • For end-point analysis, minimum and maximum incubation time are the same.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:191

1.0

Workstation assesses whether card is acceptable for analysis:

 

 

1.1   If NOT, first reading from card, reviews raw data from ID test for timing gaps between consecutive readings. [REN:PRD:341] [REN:PRD:708]

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Gaps between consecutive readings exceed time limit.

 

 

1.2   Performs data quality check (i.e. verifies that initial values for all wells are greater than card thresholds specified in the Analysis Specification). [REN:PRD:342] [REN:PRD:343]

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Initial value less than threshold (card considered empty)

 

 

 

1.3   Verifies that minimum incubation has been reached for time of call

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Minimum incubation time NOT reached for time of call.

 

 

1.4   Eliminates data spikes using algorithm specific threshold as defined in the Analysis Specification.

 

2.0

For each well, Workstation uses the biochemical-specific method (such as Slope, %age Change, Slope of %age Change), wavelength and analysis parameters specified for the well in the Analysis Specification to analyze the contents:

 

 

2.1   Calculates analysis parameters

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A4:  Early incubation positive

 

 

Alternate Flow A5:  Bio-chemical not yet dissolved (dead time not exceeded)

 

 

Alternate Flow A6:  Insufficient data to calculate analysis parameters

 

 

2.2   Determines there is a positive reaction comparing results to biochemical-specific thresholds.

 

 

Alternate Flow A7:  Reaction could not be determined

 

 

2.3   Records biochemical (well) status as ‘final’ and analysis method

 

3.0

Workstation uses results from all wells to choose an organism from claimed organisms by matching against biopatterns specified in the Analysis Specification.

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A8:  No chosen organism but maximum incubation time reached.

 

 

Alternate Flow A9:  More than three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached.

 

 

Alternate Flow A10:  Two or three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached.

 

 

Alternate Flow A11:  Missing required ID offline tests

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A12:  No single chosen organism but maximum incubation time not reached.

 

4.0

Once a single organism is chosen, Workstation determines biochemical result (example: positive, negative, weak positive, weak negative, or "null") for any remaining wells where the biochemical status is not ‘final by slope’ or ‘final by early positive’, and records biochemical status as ‘final after identification’.

 

Updated per CR-382 on 9/27/2003

 

5.0

Workstation calculates T-index and determines identification quality (% probability and confidence level) for chosen organism.

 

See Special Requirements for a list of rules related to the calculation of % probability and ID confidence for some organisms.

See Special Requirements for the algorithm to calculate percent probability from the t-index.

 

6.0

Workstation determines that the called organism is not a "slashline". [REN:PRD:257]

 

Alternate Flow A13:  Organism is a slashline

(Added per DR-317 on 5/20/2003)

 

7.0

Workstation determines if ID analysis detected an organism that requires special handling.

 

See Special Requirements for a list of rules related to the special handling of some single organism calls.

 

8.0

Workstation records card information:

  • Organism
  • % probability (if calculated)
  • confidence level (if calculated)
  • required analysis time to final result
  • test status (= ‘final’)
  • bionumber
  • biochemical reactions
  • contraindicating tests (if any-  See Special Requirements for a formula to calculate % positive for contraindicating tests)
  • supplemental tests (if any)
  • organism notes (ID analysis messages)

 

See Special Requirements for a list of rules related supplemental tests.

 

 

9.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions

None

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variants

A1.1

A2.1

For each biochemical in the ID card, the biochemical status is recorded as ‘terminated’.

 

A2.2

A2.3

A2.4

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Removed per DR-1851 on 12/17/2003.  For details related to audit, see DR-1852.

A7.1

A7.2

A8

REN:ESPEC:199

No chosen organism and maximum incubation time reached

A8.1

Workstation records test status as final, bionumber, biochemical reactions, and time of call.

 

A8.2

Workstation records organism as “unidentified” and reason (Example:  no matching biopattern exists in database).

 

A8.3

A8.4

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Removed per DR-1846 on 12/17/2003.  For details related to audit, see DR-1852.

 

A8.5

A9

REN:ESPEC:200

More than three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached

A9.1

Workstation records test status as ‘final’, bionumber, biochemical reactions, and time of call.

 

A9.2

Workstation records organism as ‘unidentified’ and reason (Example:  ‘several matching biopatterns’).

 

Developer Note:  do not record "inconclusive".  Organism recorded as "unidentified".

 

A9.3

Workstation does not record confidence level or % probability.

 

A9.4

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Removed per DR-1847 on 12/17/2003.  For details related to audit, see DR-1852.

 

A9.5

Use case ends

A10

REN:ESPEC:201

Two or three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached

A10.1

A10.1.1   For each selected organism Workstation records % probability, confidence, contraindicating tests, and organism notes.

 

A10.1.2   Other than the organisms retuned by ID analysis, the Workstation also returns a special low discrimination organism (for example:  Low Discrim Organism).

 

Rule:  Calculate the percent probability for low discrimination by normalizing the data.  See Special Requirements for details.  (Added per CR-327 on 5/8/2003).

 

 

A10.2

Workstation determines if ID analysis detected a low discrimination organism that requires special handling.  

 

See Special Requirements for a list of rules related to low discrimination organisms.

 

(Added per CR-554 and CR-320 on 5/8/2003)

 

A10.3

Workstation records the test status as ‘final’, bionumber, biochemical reactions, and time of call.

 

A10.4

Workstation records reason (for example:  “low discrimination”)

 

A10.5

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Removed per DR-1848 on 12/17/2003.  For details related to audit, see DR-1852.

 

A10.6

Use case ends

A11

REN:ESPEC:202

Missing required ID offline tests

A11.1

Workstation determines if the max incubation times has been reached.

 

A11.1.1   If max incubation time has been reached, Workstation records reason and test status as ‘qualified’

A11.1.2   If max incubation time has not been reached, Workstation records reason and test status as ‘qualified’ and analysis continues.

 

Added to support ANC.

 

A11.2

Use case ends.

A12

REN:ESPEC:203

No single chosen organism but maximum incubation time not reached

A12.1

Workstation records reason and test status as ‘preliminary’.

 

A12.2

Use case ends.

A13

REN:ESPEC:455

  Organism is a slashline

(Added per DR-317 on 5/20/2003)

 

A13.1

Workstation checks user configuration for auto slashline resolution.

[REN:PRD:257]

A13.1.1   If Lab Supervisor configured an organism for auto slashline resolution, then Workstation applies the user configured organism to the isolate.  Workstation retains the organism that comprise the slashline, and Workstation logs the event.  Updated per DR-1852

A13.1.2   If Lab Supervisor did not configure an organism for auto slashline resolution, then Workstation records the organism as "slashline" for later resolution by the Lab Tech. Workstation retains the organisms that comprise the slashline.

 

A13.2

Use case resumes at Step 7.0 of the main flow.

 

 

 

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:615

Calculation of % probability and identification confidence for single organism call or slashline organism call. (text updated per DR-1780 on 12/8/2003)

 

From the 5/16/2000 Issues meeting, users would like two parameters displayed to signify Identification quality.  The parameters include % Probability (integer, percent) and Identification Confidence (text).  The calculation of % Probability and Identification Confidence is as follows (T-index conversion):

  • Convert the T-index to % probability.  Percent probability is expressed as a “integer percent”.  The formula for the conversation is as follows:

    •  

    %probability = (0.15(T-index) + 0.85)*100

     

  • The % probability is adjusted to never display 100% or 0% on the UI or report.  The Workstation should adjust a % probability of 100 to 99%, and a % probability of 0 to 1%.  This is compatible with VITEK methodology.
  • ID Analysis returns the following text for ID Confidence based on the T-index:  Excellent, Very Good, Good, and Acceptable.  The relationship between % probability and ID confidence text is as follows:

    •  

       ID confidence         % probability

  • Excellent         96 - 99%
  • Very good         93 - 95%
  • Good         89 - 92%
  • Acceptable         85- 88%
  • The % probability calculated above may need to be adjusted to match the ID confidence returned from ID analysis.  For example, a % probability of 95.3% would be adjusted to 96% in order to match the ID confidence of "Excellent ID".  This step is necessary to maintain compatibility to VITEK 2.

 

 

 

Calculation of % probability and identification confidence for low discrimination organism calls.

 

 

  1. ID library will return a % probability for each organism by converting the t-index No change to current methodology.  See above for calculation.  The special low discrim organism (i.e. Low Discrim Organism) is not used to determine the % probability.
  2. Outside the ID library, the Workstation will normalize the % probability for each organism so the sum of all percents equals 100. The special low discrim organism (i.e. Low Discrim Organism) is not used to determine the % probability.
  3. The normalized % probability will be displayed to the user when the organism selection is made.
  4. When the user makes a selection, the normalized % probability will be replaced by the % probability calculated by the ID library.
  5. The normalized % probability will not be sent to the LIS.

 

 

Example:

 

% probability from ID            Normalized % probability              Organism

Library

 

          95%                                          34% (95/281)                      E. coli

          94%                                          33% (94/281)                      P. mirabilis

          92%                                          33% (92/281)                      C. freundii

                                                       -----------------------------

                                                         100%

 

 

 

Calculation of percent for contraindicating tests from typicity (Added per DR-1968)

 

 

If contra test result is positive then (rounded to nearest integer)

 

   % Positive = 100  * ( Positive Typicity / ( Positive Typicity +1 ) )

 

If the contra result is negative then (rounded to the nearest integer)

 

   % Positive = 100  * ( 1 / ( Negative Typicity +1 ) )     

Rule:  percents for contraindicating tests are never displayed as 100% or 0%.  For display purposes, convert 100% to 99%, and 0% to 1%.  

 

Example 1:  

 

Original % Positive is 20  ==>  Contra test is (+)

 

   Positive Typicity = 1 * ( .20 / .80 ) = .25  which is the number given in the knowledge base and currently displayed on the lab report

To convert to % positive:

 

   % Positive = 100 * ( .25 / (.25 +1) ) = 100 * ( .25 / 1.25 ) = 100 * 0.2 = 20

 

 

 

Example 2:

 

Original % Positive is 80   ==>  Contra test is (-)

 

   Negative Typicity = 100 * ( .20/.80 ) = 25  which is the number given in the knowledge base and currently displayed on the lab report

 

To convert to % positive:

 

   % Positive = 100 * ( 1 / (.25 + 1) ) = 100 * 0.8 = 80

 

 

 

Bionumber calculation

A bionumber is a numeric representation of the organism's biopattern (profile).  Biochemicals are arranged into groups of three based on well number.  Each position in the set of three has an assigned value (1, 2, or 4).  Based on the relative position in the set of three biochemicals and the result of the biochemical, a bionumber is calculated.  Wells with no biochemicals are ignored.  The following example illustrates the calculation.

 

Well number

Biochemical

Reaction

Assigned value

bionumber

GLUC

+

1

2

SUC

2

+

+

+

The bionumber for this organism would be:  137

Bionumber in Kinetic mode: When a call is made in the kinetic mode, all wells may not have finalized. Bionumber calculation however, will include ALL biochemical wells, whether they are finalized or not. At the instance a call is made, wells are interpreted + or – (no ? for this calculations) by comparing the maximum parameter value with the threshold value (+ for >=, and – for <). Then, bionumber is calculated from this profile as described above. All well results at the time of call are printed in the analysis results text file.  Input for this decision was given to Luc via e:mail and provided by Nancy Moss on September 26, 2002.
