requirement.description:
Name

Analyze SRF ID Data

Primary actor

None (abstract use case)

Goal

This document outlines the steps required to complete additional identification analysis.  If enabled in Workstation configuration, organism identification is attempted by SRF identification analysis after Renaissance identification analysis completes.  The purpose of SRF analysis is to extend the identification knowledge base in order to identify less frequently encountered organisms.

Preconditions
  • Biochemical well analysis is completed by Renaissance identification analysis (biochemicals are already interpreted as positive or negative).
  • SRF analysis begins when Renaissance identification analysis completes.
  • SRF is enabled in Workstation configuration.

Assumptions
  • Usually one identification result is generated per test.
  • Evaluate biopattern uses all available well data.  

 

  • SRF identification analysis uses end-point mode and not kinetic mode of analysis.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:204

1.0

Workstation uses results from all wells to choose an organism from SRF organisms by matching against biopatterns specified in the SRF database. [REN:PRD:345]

 

 

Alternate Flow A1:  No chosen organism but maximum incubation time reached

 

 

Alternate Flow A2:  More than three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached

 

 

Alternate Flow A3:  Two or three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached.

 

2.0

Workstation calculates T-index and determines identification quality (% probability and confidence level) for chosen organism (see Notes below for a version of this algorithm). [REN:PRD:347]

 

Rule:  If the isolate identification is "unidentified or inconclusive", then do not calculate percent probability or identification confidence.

 

 

3.0

Workstation records card information:

  • SRF analysis organism name
  • SRF analysis % probability (updated on 7/1)
  • SRF analysis confidence level [REN:PRD:346]

 

4.0

Use Case ends.

post-conditions

None

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:205

No chosen organism and maximum incubation time reached

A1.1

Workstation records organism as “unidentified” and reason (Example:  no matching biopattern exists in SRF database).

 

A1.2

Workstation does not record confidence level or %probability.

 

A1.3

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Updated per DR-1852 on 12/17/2003.

 

A1.4

Use case ends.

A2

REN:ESPEC:206

More than three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached

A2.1

Workstation records organism as ‘unidentified’ and reason (Example:  ‘several matching biopatterns’).

 

Developer note:  do not record "inconclusive".  Organism recorded as "unidentified".

 

 

A2.2

Workstation does not record confidence level or %probability.

 

A2.3

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Updated per DR-1852 on 12/17/2003.

 

A2.4

Use case ends

A3

REN:ESPEC:207

Two or three chosen organisms and maximum incubation time reached

A3.1

For each selected organism Workstation records % probability and confidence.

 

Rule:  If the isolate identification is "low discrimination", then follow the rules in Special Requirements for the calculation of percent probability and identification confidence. (Added per CR-327 on 5/9/2003)

 

 

A3.2

Workstation records reason (for example:  “low discrimination”)

 

 

A3.3

Workstation logs the event including card bar code, accession ID, isolate number, and card definition (example:  ID-GNB).  Updated per DR-1852 on 12/17/2003.

 

A3.4

Use case ends.

Special Requirements

Calculation of % probability and identification confidence for single organism call or slashline organism call.

 

See Special Requirements section of the Analyze ID Data use case for details.

 

Calculation of % probability and identification confidence for low discrimination organism call or slashline organism call.

 

See Special Requirements section of the Analyze ID Data use case for details.

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Combine SRF and ID Analysis Results
requirement.description:
Name

Combine SRF and ID Analysis Results

Primary actor

None (abstract use case)

Goal

This use case combines the results of SRF analysis with ID analysis results This is used by another use case entitled Analyze SRF Data.

Preconditions
  • ID Analysis completes and returns either:  single organism, low discrimination, slashline, unidentified, or inconclusive.
  • SRF Analysis completes and returns either:  single organism, low discrimination, unidentified, or inconclusive,
  • SRF analysis is enabled in user configuration.

Assumptions
  • The Lab Supervisor has done maintenance in SRF to associated biopatterns with an SRF organism.

Trigger

This will be triggered when SRF analysis is finished.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:456

[REN:PRD:345]

1.0

This use case starts when SRF analysis has completed for an identification card.

 

2.0

Workstation compares the results of ID analysis with the results of SRF analysis to determine what to display to the Lab Tech.  Findings are as follows:

 

2.1   Workstation determines that the ID Analysis for the biopattern is a single organism.

2.2   Workstation determines that the SRF Analysis for the biopattern is a single organism.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  ID Analysis is not a single organism or SRF analysis is not a single organism.

 

3.0

Workstation merges the ID results with the SRF results and reports the following based on the findings in Step 2.0:

 

3.1   Org ID:         Low discrim (ID: single org; SRF:single org)

3.2   ID % Probability:   Percent

3.3   SRF % Probability:   Percent

3.4   Merged confidence:   Low discrimination

3.5   ID Contra tests:      If any (ID analysis)

3.6   SRF Contra tests:   none

 

 

 

4.0

Workstation stores the merged result set for display to the Lab Tech.

 

5.0

Use Case Ends

 

 

 

post-conditions
  • Workstation merges ID analysis results with SRF analysis results and stores for later display to the Lab Tech..

Step

Exception

Branching Action

Step

Variants

ID Analysis is not a single organism or SRF analysis is not a single organism.

A1.1

There are many different combinations of ID analysis results and SRF analysis results.  Please see the table below Special Requirements for details on processing the different conditions.

 

A1.2

Use case resumes at Step 4.0 of the main flow.

requirement.description:
Name

Boot Renaissance Workstation

Primary actor

Renaissance user (generalized from Lab Tech or Lab Supervisor), or non-human external actor

Goal

Boot the Renaissance Workstation into Windows, starting the Renaissance Core Server, Device Communication Service, ID Service, AST Service, AES Service, and BCI Link (RS232 and FTP) Service.  Logging into Windows is NOT a part of this use case.

Preconditions
  • Workstation is powered on

Assumptions
  • The following servers are registered with Windows for automatic startup upon boot, and will run under the Administrator account:
    • Shutdown Daemon
    • Renaissance Core Server
    • Device Communication Service
    • ID Service
    • AST Service
    • AES Service
    • BCI Link Service (Windows service name is BCI Net)
    • Naming service

Trigger

Workstation boot process

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:156

[REN:PRD:372]

[REN:PRD:380] [REN:PRD:750]

1.0

The use case starts when the Workstation is booted.

 

2.0

Workstation starts the following processes, in the following order, through the Administrator account:

 

 

 

2.1    Naming service

 

 

2.2    Shutdown Monitor

 

 

2.3    Device Communication

 

 

2.4    Renaissance Core Server

2.4.1  Workstation executes Initiate Version Verification use case. (Added per DR 837 on 8/8/2003)

 

 

 

2.5    AST analysis

 

 

2.6    ID analysis

 

 

2.7    AES PC (AES PC is integrated into Renaissance.  There is no separate service.  Removed on 10/10/2003)

 

 

2.8    BCI Link (Windows service name is BCI Net)

 

 

 

 

 

The Renaissance Core Server process successfully connects to the Device Communication, AST, ID, AES, and BCI Link processes.

 

 

 

Rule: At Core startup, the VITEK 2 System restarts communication with FMLA-IT, and sends a message indicating that the Workstation is no longer busy. [REN:PRD:750]

 

Rule: At Core startup, the VITEK 2 System sends the following information to FLMA-IT, if FMLA-IT mode is enabled in General Configuration:

 

1.  Name of the VITEK 2 Systems PC (from the OS; for example:

BMXHOST1)

2.  Location of the computer in the lab (from general config)

3.  List of instruments (name and serial number)

4.  Version of VITEK 2 System (e.g.: 05.01 – just major and minor numbers)

5.  PC Location  [REN:PRD:725]

 

Rule: At Core startup, the VITEK 2 System sends the following information to VILINK (via SysUtil), if VILINK Message Transfer is enabled in General Configuration:

 

1.  Card Usage Message. [REN:PRD:731]

 

 

3.0

Workstation determines if a database restore has been done.  If so, Workstation logs the event in the application audit trail.  If not, no action is taken.

 

Tester note:  A file placed in the following location can be used to indicate if a database restore has been completed:  externalization\RestoreAudit\RestoreAudit.txt.

 

 

4.0

Use case ends   

post-conditions
  • The Workstation is booted into Windows, but not logged in
  • The following processes are running: Renaissance Core Server, Device Communication Service, ID Service, AST Service, AES Service, Naming service, and BCI Link Service
  • The Renaissance Core Server has successfully connected to the Device Communication, AST, ID, AES, and BCI Link processes.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

N/A

N/A

Special Requirements

None

requirement.description:
Name

Detect Process Crash

Primary actor

A non-human “Alive Detector” actor (e.g. another process)

Goal

Detect the unexpected exit of the Renaissance Service or process.  Any exit of a non-GUI process is unexpected.

Preconditions
  • Boot Renaissance Workstation use case has been executed
  • Start Renaissance Application use case may have been executed

Assumptions
  • None

Trigger

A Renaissance process exits unexpectedly.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:157

[REN:PRD:11] [REN:PRD:12]

1.0

The use case starts when the “Alive Detector” actor determines that a Renaissance process has exited unexpectedly.

 

2.0

“Alive Detector” informs the user that an unexpected Renaissance process exit has been detected, and points the user towards a log file, which he/she should forward to the bioMerieux Renaissance Team for debugging.

 

3.0

Workstation asks user to confirm that a Shutdown and Reboot will occur.  User can delay Shutdown and Reboot for a limited period of time, but cannot cancel it.

 

4.0

Workstation executes Shutdown Renaissance Workstation use case.

1. Core Server,

requirement.description:
[See attachment TTRM673308222614776878.wmf]

Figure 7:  UC- End of Day Processing

 

This activity describes how information flows through the Renaissance system.  There are business rules that describe how information transitions from the active workspace to the inactive workspace.  In addition, there are business rules that describe how information leaves the inactive workspace.  With the exception of maintaining AES export information, User configuration settings dictate how these transitions work.

workflow-event.notes: System event generated by rule [Move to Draft] Actions: Enter [Auto Sort] event

requirement.description:
Name

End of Day Processing

Primary actor

Renaissance Timer

Goal

Oversee end of day processing for the Renaissance application.  Tasks include the management of the active workspace, inactive workspace, status/alarm workspace, and BCI workspace.

Preconditions
  • Renaissance client is not running.

Assumptions
  • End of day processing occurs when the Lab Tech or Lab Supervisor is not using the system.  This usually occurs late at night in most laboratories.  This is also the time when BCI transactions are at a minimum for upload and downloads.  The usual time is around 3:00 AM for VITEK and VITEK 2.
  • The Renaissance client cannot be started once end of day processing has begun.

 

Need to update the Ren startup use case to reflect that the client cannot be started once end of processing has started.

Trigger

Renaissance timer indicates that end of day processing should begin.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:411

[REN:PRD:57]

[REN:PRD:65]

1.0

Use case starts when the Renaissance timer indicates that is it time for end of day processing to begin.

 

2.0

Workstation verifies that the installed components (i.e. program files, knowledge bases, etc.) are valid for use with the current version of the Renaissance application.

 

3.1   Workstation executes Initiate Version Verification use case. (Added per DR-837 on 8/8/2003)

 

Developer note:  if the Workstation determines that there is a problem with the installed component versions, the Renaissance application (Renaissance client) will not start.  This condition is handled as an alternate course in the above use case, and not repeated as an alternate course in this use case.

 

3.0

Workstation determines that there are no remote users logged on. [REN:PRD:700] [REN:PRD:750]

 

Alternate Flow A3: Workstation determines that there are remote users logged on.

 

4.0

Workstation determines that the Renaissance client is not running.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Renaissance client is running.

 

5.0

5.1   Workstation notifies all attached Instruments that daily workspace cleanup is being started.

 

Developer note:  this will probably stop the communication service.  Instrument needs to be made aware that the workstation will be busy for a little while.

 

6.0

6.1   If enabled in General Configuration, workstation creates the card usage message. If not enabled, use case resumes at next step. Information in the message includes:

 

1 – Card Type (name, i.e. AST-GP55, etc., ID is numeric (241))

2 – Card start date / time (date/time loaded in the instrument)

3 – Card end date / time (date/time card ejected from the instrument)

4 – Card status  (final, terminated, etc.)

5 – Card bar code

6 – Type of isolate (QC or non-QC)

7 – Date of message creation

 

Rule: One message contains all cards for that day.

 

Developer note: Since EOD runs in the early morning hours for the previous day, EOD pulls isolates that are T minus 1 (where T = current system date).  For example:  The system works all day Monday, EOD runs at 1:00AM Tuesday.  EOD pulls the isolates from Tuesday minus 1, or Monday's information  [REN:PRD:731]

 

Rule: Cards that do not have a status of “Preliminary” are counted.

 

6.2   FMLA-IT will be notified that the Workstation is busy.

6.3   Workstation will disable communications with FMLA-IT. [REN:PRD:750]

 

 

7.0

Workstation completes daily workspace cleanup.

 

7.1   Workstation executes Complete Daily Workspace Maintenance use case.

 

8.0

If there are no errors returned from Step 3.0, Workstation backups the Renaissance database.

 

8.1   If enabled in configuration, Workstation executes an unattended backup by executing the Backup Isolate Data use case.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Problems detected from workspace cleanup.

 

Developer note:  the Renaissance services are stopped as a result of executing the backup use case.

 

Developer note:  some customers (usually internal, and some Industry) elect not to complete automatic backup.  See Schedule Backup use case for details.

 

9.0

Workstation reboots the Workstation by executing the Boot Renaissance Workstation use case.

 

Developer note:  this helps to resolve any Windows memory leaks and a clean operating environment for Renaissance application.

 

10.0

Workstation starts all required Renaissance services following reboot, except Renaissance client.

 

Developer note:  since Instrument communication is again started, the Instrument is aware that the Renaissance services are ready to receive buffered information.

 

11.0

Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.

 

12.0

Use case ends

post-conditions
  • Database maintenance complete, isolate backup performed, and Workstation rebooted.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:412

Renaissance client is running

 

A1.1

Workstation alerts the Renaissance User (Lab Tech or Lab Supervisor) that required file maintenance must be started.  Renaissance user is asked to close the Renaissance application.  Renaissance user can elect to close the Renaissance client.

 

A1.2

A1.2.1   Workstation determines if the Renaissance user has closed the Renaissance application.  If so, the use case resumes at step 4.0 of the main flow once the Renaissance client is closed.

 

A1.2.2   If the Renaissance client was not closed by the Renaissance User (Lab Tech or Lab Supervisor), then the Workstation waits for 3 minutes.  If stopped, use case resumes at Step 4.0 of the main flow.  If still not stopped, alerts the Renaissance user (Lab Tech or Lab Supervisor), and closes the Renaissance client.  Unsaved data is lost.  Use case resumes at Step 4.0 of the Main flow.

 

 

A1.3

If at any time the Renaissance client is closed, the use case resumes at Step 5.0 of the main flow.

A2

REN:ESPEC:413

Errors detected from workspace cleanup

A2.1

Workstation does not perform an unattended backup.

 

A2.2

If physically possible, the problem along with its description, are recorded as a Renaissance alarm.  In this case the alarm would indicate that an unattended backup was not performed because of a problem with workspace maintenance.  This alarm is displayed to the next Renaissance user to log onto Renaissance following View and Maintain Alarms use case.

 

Developer note:  this step may not be possible if the database is in such state that information cannot be stored.  

 

A2.3

Use case resumes at Step 9.0 of the main flow.

A3

REN:ESPEC:717

Workstation determines that there are remote users logged on.

A3.1

Workstation notifies remote users that end of day is about to begin – please log off.

 

A3.2

Workstation waits for user to log off. If user doesn’t log off within the designated timeframe, the system will automatically log the user off. [REN:PRD:700] [REN:PRD:750]

 

A3.3

Use case resumes at step 3 of main flow.

 

 

 

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:984

Business Rules:

 

The system checks to be certain that only one instance of end of day processing (EOD) is running at one time.  If an instance of EOD is currently running, the system does not start a new instance.

requirement.description:
Name

Complete daily workspace maintenance.

Primary actor

Renaissance Timer

Goal

Maintain the active workspace (patient, isolate, and QC), maintain the inactive workspace (inactive isolate reports, and cumulative QC isolates), maintain status/alarm workspace, and maintain BCI alarm workspace.

Preconditions
  • Renaissance client cannot be started during workspace cleanup.

Assumptions
  • None

Trigger

Renaissance timer indicates it is time for workspace cleanup.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:414

[REN:PRD:57]

[REN:PRD:65]

1.0

Use case starts when it is time to begin workspace cleanup.

 

2.0

Workstation completes maintenance on the active workspace.

 

2.1   Workstation executes the Maintain Active Workspace use case.

 

3.0

Workstation completes maintenance on the inactive workspace.

 

3.1   Workstation executes the Maintain Inactive Workspace use case.

 

4.0

Workstation completes maintenance on the BCI workspace.

 

4.1   Workstation executes the Maintain BCI Workspace use case.

 

Developer note:  this functionality is provided by BCI Link.

 

5.0

If 21 CFR 11 enabled, Workstation determines the last time isolate reports were archived to CD.

 

5.1   If the difference from the current date is more than 90 days (approximately 3 months) 180 days (approximately 6 months), then an instrument alarm is recorded and displayed to the next Renaissance user (Lab Tech or Lab Supervisor) to log onto Renaissance. [REN:PRD:756]

5.2   Other wise, no action is taken.

 

Marketing decision on time frame documented on 4/18/2003.

Updated per CR-7350 11/10/2009 for release 05.01.

 

5.3   Workstation will generate an instrument alarm when there are 3,600 isolates in the inactive workspace that are candidates for archiving.  Even if acknowledged, the alarm will continue to be generated daily until an archive is created. [REN:PRD:756]

 

Updated per CR-7394 11/10/2009 for release 05.01

 

Developer note:  how much archived isolate information (isolate reports, previous reports, and isolate audit) will fit onto one CD? Can we estimate the number of isolates?  I am trying to avoid issues with saving isolate information by spanning CDs.

 

6.0

Workstation determines that there were no errors/problems associated with workspace maintenance.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Problem detected during workspace maintenance.

 

7.0

Use case ends.

post-conditions

 

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:415

Problem detected during workspace maintenance

A1.1

If physically possible, the problem along with its description, are recorded as a Renaissance alarm.  This alarm is displayed to the next Renaissance user to log onto Renaissance following View and Maintain Alarms use case.

 

Developer note:  this step may not be possible if the database is in such state that information cannot be stored.  

 

A1.2

Use case resumes at Step 6.0 o the main flow.

 

 

 

A2

None

A2.1

None

 

 

 

A3

None

A3.1

None

 

 

 

Special Requirements

None

requirement.description:
Name

Maintain active workspace

Primary actor

Renaissance Timer

Goal

Maintain the active workspace (patient, isolate, cassette, instrument status, alarms, BCI antibiotic translation codes, and QC).

Preconditions
  • Renaissance client cannot be started during workspace cleanup.  

Assumptions
  • If not linked to an isolate, a specimen will remain in the patient workspace for 7 days after the specimen creation date. (Updated per CR-3449)
  • If a patient is not linked to any specimens, then the patient is deleted from the patient workspace.
  • Depending on the configuration of long-term data storage, or 21 CFR 11, aged isolates are either deleted or moved to the inactive workspace.
  • The patient lab report and the QC lab report are transitioned from the active workspace to the inactive workspace based on user configurations.  Other reports are not retained.
  • Aged QC isolates are moved to the "inactive" workspace.
  • Happy path:  21 CFR 11 enabled, or long-term data storage enabled.

Trigger

Renaissance timer indicates it is time for workspace cleanup in the active workspace.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:416

1.0

Use case starts when it is time to begin active workspace cleanup.

 

2.0

Patient Management

 

If patient demographics enabled, workstation maintains patients and specimens in the active workspace by removing aged specimens not linked to an isolate.  In 08.01, this is expanded to include HL7 order management (ORB) information. Workstation applies the following criteria in order to delete specimens:

 

2.1   If a specimen or ORB is not linked to an isolate, and the difference between the specimen creation date and current date is more than 7 days, then specimen is deleted from the patient workspace. (Updated per CR-3449)  [REN:PRD:632]

 

2.2   If a patient is not linked to any specimens, then the patient and ORB information is deleted from the patient workspace. [REN:PRD:56] (Patients are removed from the active workspace.  Edits are not possible.  Only the lab report is retained.

 

Rule:  End of Day removes any patient that does not have a specimen when this condition is detected.  Note:  this condition can occur if the last  specimen from a patient  is moved to a new patient.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

3.0

Isolate Management (isolates with Lab ID, isolate number)

 

Workstation maintains isolates with a lab ID and isolate number in the active workspace by removing aged isolates.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove isolates:

 

3.1   Isolate is qualified / qualified duplicate, or “approved” (green square). [REN:PRD:791]

3.2   Isolate does not need to be "reviewed".

3.3   Isolate does not need to be "approved".

3.4   The difference between the isolate creation date and the current date is greater than the user-defined parameter for isolates to remain in the active workspace.

3.5   If all conditions in Steps 3.1 - 3.4 are satisfied, then the isolate is flagged as aged from the active workspace.

3.6   If any condition in Steps 3.1-3.4 is not satisfied, then the isolate is not flagged to be removed from the active workspace. [REN:PRD:57]

 

Isolate Management (isolates with no Lab ID and no isolate number)

 

Workstation maintains isolates in the active workspace with no Lab ID or isolate number by removing aged isolates.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to age this type of isolate: [REN:PRD:785]

 

3.7   The aging of isolates with no Lab ID or Isolate Number is enabled.

3.8   Card analysis is preliminary or final.

3.9   Isolate does not have a Lab ID or Isolate Number

3.10   The difference between the isolate creation date and the current date is greater than the user-defined parameter for isolates  with no Lab ID or Isolate number to be removed.

 

Developer and tester note:  these special configuration settings are in the Core LAX file. The default value is 60 days to retain isolates with no lab ID and no isolate number.

 

3.11   If all conditions in Steps 3.7 - 3.10 are satisfied, then the isolate is flagged as aged from the active workspace.

3.12   If any condition in Steps 3.7 – 3.10 is not satisfied, then the isolate is not flagged to be removed from the active workspace

 

 

 

 

4.0

Workstation determines that either long-term data storage configuration parameter is enabled, or 21 CFR 11 configuration parameter is enabled.

 

Non-qualified patient isolates

4.1   If an isolate is determined to be aged from the active workspace, and is not qualified, then the isolate and related components (i.e. isolate lab report, all previous versions of the isolate lab report, and isolate audit trail) are flagged as "inactive".  Other information related to the isolate (i.e. raw data) is removed from the active workspace. [REN:PRD:65] (Isolates are moved from the active workspace.  Edits are not possible.  Only the lab report / AES detail report is retained.)

4.2   Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.

 

Qualified patient isolates [REN:PRD:791]

4.3   If an isolate is determined to be aged from the active workspace and is qualified, then the isolate and related components (i.e. isolate lab report, all previous versions of the isolate lab report) are deleted.  Other information related to the isolate (i.e. raw data) is also deleted from the active workspace.

4.4   Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case

 

RULE:  Qualified QC isolates are not to be deleted by the system.

RULE:  If there are a large number of isolates that must be deleted and aged or deleted, the system will limit the number to 2500 isolates.  This will allow end of day to complete in a timely fashion. This value can be changed by third level support (Core.lax).

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

Alternate flow A2:  Long-term data storage and 21 CFR 11 configuration parameters are both disabled.

 

5.0

QC Management

 

Workstation maintains QC isolates in the active workspace by removing aged QC isolates.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove QC isolates:

 

5.1   QC isolate is not qualified.

5.2   QC isolate does not need to be "reviewed".

5.3   QC isolate does not need to be "approved".

5.4   The difference between the QC isolate creation date and the current date is greater than the user-defined parameter for isolates to remain in the active workspace.

5.5   If all conditions in Steps 5.1 - 5.4 are satisfied, then the QC isolate is flagged as aged from the active workspace.

5.6   If any condition in Steps 5.1 - 5.4 is not satisfied, then the QC isolate is not flagged to be removed from the active workspace.

 

6.0

6.1   If a QC isolate is determined to be aged from the active workspace, then the QC isolate and related QC components (i.e. QC isolate lab report, all previous versions of the QC isolate lab report, and QC isolate audit trail) are flagged as "inactive".  Other information related to the isolate (i.e. raw data) is removed from the active workspace. [REN:PRD:309] (QC isolates are removed from the active workspace.  Edits are not possible.  Only the lab report is retained.).

6.2   Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.

 

Developer note:  for a QC isolate, the user must be able to enter QC comments related to the isolate.  This is true even if the QC isolate is no longer in the active workspace.  See the View QC Results and View QC Cumulative Results use cases for details.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

7.0

Cassette Management

 

Workstation maintains cassettes in the active workspace by removing aged cassettes.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove a cassette:

 

7.1   Cassettes that have been loaded into an Instrument (load and go) which have no associated isolates in the active workspace are flagged as aged from the active workspace.

 

Rule:  Cassettes which contained isolates with no Lab ID or Isolate number are also removed if the isolates contained in the cassette are removed. [REN:PRD:785]

 

8.0

8.1   If a cassette is determined to be aged from the active workspace, then the cassette is deleted from the active workspace.  

 

Developer Note:  the Workstation will not automatically delete a virtual cassette.  The user must delete a virtual cassette manually. See Maintain Virtual Cassette use case for details.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

9.0

Instrument Status Management

 

Workstation maintains Instrument status information (temperature readings and optic checks) in the active workspace by removing aged messages.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to delete messages:

[REN:PRD:352]

 

9.1   If the difference between the message creation date and current date is more than 4 months, then the message is deleted from the active workspace.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

Developer note:  this applies to Instrument status information for all Instruments attached to the Workstation.

 

10.0

Alarm Management

 

Workstation maintains alarms in the active workspace by removing aged alarms.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to delete alarms:

 

10.1   If the difference between the alarm creation date and current date is more than 31 days, then the alarm is deleted from the active workspace.

10.2   If the number of retained alarms exceeds 1000, then the oldest alarms are deleted until the maximum number retained is 1000.

[REN:PRD:480]

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

Developer note:  Step 10.0 applies to Instrument, Renaissance, and BCI alarms.  Also, there is no special processing needed for unacknowledged alarms.  Steps in 10 apply to both acknowledged or unacknowledged alarms.

 

11.0

Customer deleted Isolates, either QC or non-QC

 

If 21 CFR 11 is enabled, the Workstation maintains deleted isolates in the active workspace by removing aged isolates.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to age deleted isolates:

 

11.1   The difference between the isolate creation date and the current date is greater than the user-defined parameter for isolates to remain in the active workspace.

11.2   21 CFR 11 mode is enabled in user configuration

11.3   If all conditions in Steps 11.1 - 11.2 are satisfied, then the deleted isolate is flagged as aged from the active workspace.  This includes QC and non-QC isolates.

[REN:PRD:56] [REN:PRD:428]

 

Developer note:  if 21 CFR 11 is not enabled, then the isolate is deleted from the active workspace after user confirmation.  For details, please see alternate courses in the View and Maintain Test Results use case for details.

 

12.0

Workstation determines that 21 CFR 11 configuration parameter is enabled.

 

12.1   If a deleted isolate is determined to be aged from the active workspace, then the isolate and related components (i.e. isolate lab report, all previous versions of the isolate lab report, and isolate audit trail) are flagged as "inactive".  Other information related to the isolate (i.e. raw data) is removed from the active workspace.

12.2   Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

13.0

Delete aged card bar codes [REN:PRD:99] [REN:PRD:100] [REN:PRD:142] (Added per DR-1413 on 10/6/2003)

 

Workstation maintains a list of card bar codes in the active workspace by removing aged bar codes.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to delete alarms:

 

13.1   If the difference between the card bar code creation date and current date is more than 31 days, then the card bar code is deleted from the active workspace.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

14.0

Download Isolate Information Maintenance from BCI, Myla, or HL7

 

Workstation maintains download isolate information (organisms and AST offline tests) in the active workspace by removing aged information, both linked and not linked to an isolate.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to delete downloaded isolate information: [REN:PRD:735]

 

Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove download information (organism and AST offline tests):

 

14.1   Downloaded isolate information is not linked to an isolate, and the criterion in General Configuration (Maintain Isolate Download (days)) has been met.

  1. Organisms
    1. AST Offline Tests

      2. 14.2   Downloaded isolate information is linked to isolate(s), the last isolate linked has been removed from the active workspace, and criterion in General Configuration (Maintain Isolate Download (days)) has been met or exceeded.

      1. Organisms
      2. AST Offline Tests

      14.3   If either of the conditions in Steps 14.1 – 14.2 are satisfied, then the download isolate information is flagged as aged from the active workspace.

      14.4   If both conditions in Steps 14.1 – 14.2 are not satisfied, then the download isolate information is not flagged to be removed from the active workspace. [REN:PRD:735]

    2. Workstation removes information flagged as aged from the active workspace.

     

    Note:  as part of 07.01 (partially implemented in Maintenance Release 3), an alarm is generated if an aged download organism or AST offline test cannot be removed from the system.  See ALT 1 for details.

     

    Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

15.0

Management of BCI and HL7 Organism/Antibiotic Translation Codes

 

Workstation maintains BCI and HL7 Organism and Antibiotic translation codes ‘flagged’ as ‘legacy’ in the active workspace.

 

15.1   Workstation searches the active workspace for isolates associated with the translation codes flagged as ‘legacy’.

15.1.1   If not found, workstation permanently removes the BCI and HL7 Translation code flagged as ‘legacy’ from the system.

15.1.2   If removed, the workstation logs the event in the EOD log file.

15.2   If found workstation takes no action. [REN:PRD:719]

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

Developer note: Antibiotic or Organism translation codes are those that are flagged as ‘legacy’ when they have been deleted from the knowledgebase, but are still attached to isolates in the active workspace.

 

16.0

Management of Orphan AES Graphic

 

Workstation maintains AES Graphic indicated as “orphan” in the active workspace.

 

16.1   Workstation searches the active workspace for orphan AES graphic.

16.1.1   If found, Workstation removes them using the following algorithm:  50 batches of 40 records per EOD session, for a total of 2000 entities.

16.1.2   If removed, the workstation logs the event in the EOD log file.

16.2   If not found workstation takes no action.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

 

17.0

Management of Card Usage Information

 

Workstation maintains Card usage information.

 

17.1   Workstation uses the users the parameter in general  configuration to determine when to age card usage information from the system.

17.1.1   If found to be aged Workstation removes it from the active workspace.   If removed, the workstation logs the event in the EOD log file.

17.1.2   If found not to be ages, no action is taken..

 

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

 

18.0

Management of orphan taxons (organisms)

 

Workstation maintains organisms (taxon; slashline / low discrim) results that are not being referenced in isolate view as a result of an organism deletion or select and move.  

 

18.1   Workstation scans the active workspace for organisms which are no longer being referenced by an isolate.  

18.1.1   If found they are deleted by the EOD process.

18.1.2   The end of day log files contain a count of any removed from the active workspace.

 

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

Developers and tester note:  Done as part of an AR fix for AR-8669

 

19.0

General isolate and cassette cleanup

 

EOD maintains the active workspace by removing the following isolates and associated cassettes.  This was done to mitigate issues with cassette processing in the active workspace.

 

1.  Isolates with no assay

2.  Isolates with reconciled virtual cassette but not in reconciliation record

3.  Isolates with reconciled virtual cassette in reconciliation record but no associated real cassette

4.  Isolate with reconciled virtual cassette in reconciliation record and associated real cassette is complete

5.  Associated cassettes with removed isolates

 

20.0

Management of BCI Link files (operation logs, transition logs, real-time traces)

 

Workstation maintains backup files managed by BCI Link.  Based on lax file configuration, Workstation removes aged BCI link backup folder.

 

 

20.1   Workstation searches BCI Link backup folder for aged information using setting in the Core.lax file (bci.max.backup.files.age; default 31 days)

20.1.1   If found, workstation permanently removed the BCI Link folder

20.1.2   If removed, the workstation logs the event in the EOD log file.

20.2   If not found workstation takes no action

 

 

 

 

 

 

21.0

Management of custom AES Parameter Sets

 

In order to help mitigate performance issues associated with the creation of custom guidelines in AES, the end of day process shall create 1 copy of each unique predefined guideline in AES configuration.  Since the copy is created when EOD runs, the time it takes to create a custom guideline when actually performed by a Lab Supervisor is much faster.  Steps are as follows:

 

21.1   Workstation scans AES Configuration for custom guidelines associated with each predefined guidelines that have not been created by a Lab Supervisor.   

21.1.1   If no candidate copy is found, EOD creates a copy ready for use by the Lab Supervisor if customization is needed.

21.1.2   If a candidate copy is found, no action is taken.

 

RULE:  The system does not create a copy of parameter sets.  The system creates copies of each breakpoint and therapeutic correction guidelines if one does not already exist.

 

 

22.0

Management of .pdf reports in Externalization folder

 

Workstation maintains .pdf reports in the externalization folder.

 

 

22.1   Workstation searches externalization folder for aged information using setting in the Core.lax file (REN.config.externalizationFolder.pdf.daysToKeepFiles; default 7 days)

22.1.1   If found, workstation permanently removes aged .pdf reports

22.1.2   If removed, the workstation logs the event in the EOD log file.

22.2   If not found workstation takes no action

 

 

Developer and tester note:  there may be multiple sub folders created under day of the week for .pdf reports.  One folder could be for the automatic printing of .pdf reports.  Another folder could be for the .pdf reports created from utilities.

 

 

 

23.0

Management of backup files in Externalization folder

 

Workstation maintains backups in the externalization folder.

 

 

22.1   Workstation searches externalization folder for aged information using setting in the Core.lax file (????; default 7 days)

22.1.1   If found, workstation permanently removes aged  backup.

22.1.2   If removed, the workstation logs the event in the EOD log file.

22.2   If not found workstation takes no action

 

 

 

24.0

Use case ends

post-conditions

 

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:417

Workstation detects a problem

A1.1

Workstation records that a problem occurred and the reason. In the case of not being able to remove download information (organism and/or AST offline test, then a VITEK 2 Systems alarm is generated alerting the Lab Supervisor of the problem.  In this case, alarm information includes:  description of the problem, organism code, organism name, and accession number (lab ID + isolate number).

 

Developer note:  details on how this alternate course is handled are recorded in the Complete Daily Workspace Maintenance use case.

 

A1.2

Use case resumes in the step following the exception.

A2

REN:ESPEC:418

Long-term data storage and 21 CFR 11 configuration parameters are both disabled

A2.1

If an isolate is eligible to be removed, then the isolate and all related components are deleted from the active workspace.

 

RULE:  If there are a large number of isolates that must be aged or deleted, the system will limit the number to 2500 isolates.  This will allow end of day to complete in a timely fashion. This value can be changed by thread level support (Core.lax).

 

 

A2.2

Use case resumes at Step 5.0 of the main flow.

A3

None

A3.1

None

 

 

 

A4

None

A4.1

None

Special Requirements

None

workflow-event.notes: System event generated by rule [Move to Draft] Actions: Enter [Auto Sort] event

requirement.description:
Name

Maintain inactive workspace

Primary actor

Renaissance Timer

Goal

Maintain the inactive workspace (isolate reports and QC).

Preconditions
  • Renaissance client cannot be started during workspace cleanup.  

Assumptions
  • Happy path:  21 CFR 11 enabled, or long-term data storage is enabled.
  • If 21 CFR 11 is enabled, then isolate reports are not removed from the Workstation if they have not been archived.

Trigger

Renaissance timer indicates it is time for workspace cleanup in the inactive workspace.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:419

1.0

Use case starts when it is time to begin inactive workspace cleanup.

 

2.0

Cumulative Patient Isolate and Audit Management (Isolate Reports)

 

Workstation maintains isolate reports in the inactive workspace by removing aged isolate reports.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove isolates:

 

2.1   If 21 CFR 11 enabled, isolates must be flagged as "archived".

2.2   If there are more than 50,000 isolate reports in the inactive workspace, then the oldest isolate reports are flagged to be removed from the inactive workspace to keep the number of isolate reports near 50,000.

2.3   If all conditions in Steps 2.1 - 2.2 are satisfied, then the isolate is flagged as aged from the inactive workspace.

2.4   If any condition in Steps 2.1-2.2 is not satisfied, then the isolate is not flagged to be removed from the inactive workspace. [REN:PRD:58]

 

 

3.0

3.1   If an isolate report is determined to be aged from the inactive workspace, then the isolate and all related components (i.e. lab report, all previous versions of the isolate lab report, and isolate audit trail) are deleted.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

5.0

Cumulative QC Isolate and Audit Management

 

Workstation maintains QC isolates in the inactive workspace by removing aged QC isolates.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove QC isolates:

 

5.1   If 21 CFR 11 enabled, isolates must be flagged as "archived".

5.2   If there are more than 5,000 QC isolates in the inactive workspace, then the oldest QC isolates are flagged to be removed from the inactive workspace to keep the number of QC isolates near 5,000.

5.3   If all conditions in Steps 5.1 - 5.2 are satisfied, then the isolate is flagged as aged from the inactive workspace.

5.4   If any condition in Steps 5.1-5.2 is not satisfied, then the isolate is not flagged to be removed from the inactive workspace. [REN:PRD:302]

 

6.0

6.1   If a QC isolate is determined to be aged from the inactive workspace, then the QC isolate is deleted.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

7.0

Deleted Isolates in the Inactive Workspace

 

Workstation maintains deleted isolate reports in the inactive workspace by removing aged isolate reports.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove isolates:

 

7.1   If 21 CFR 11 enabled, isolates must be flagged as "archived".

7.2   If the condition in Steps 7.1 is satisfied, then the isolate is flagged as aged from the inactive workspace.

7.3   If the condition in Step 7.1 is not satisfied, then the isolate is not flagged to be removed from the inactive workspace.

[REN:PRD:273]

 

 

8.0

If an isolate report is determined to be aged from the inactive workspace, then the isolate and all related components (i.e. lab report, all previous versions of the isolate lab report, and isolate audit trail) are deleted.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

 

9.0

Application Audit Trail Management

 

Workstation maintains application audit events in the active and inactive workspace by removing aged audit events.  Workstation applies the following criteria in order to remove aged application audit events:

 

9.1   If 21 CFR 11 enabled, the application audit event must be flagged as "archived".

9.2   If 21 CFR 11 is disabled, and the difference between the audit creation date and the current date is greater than 30 days.

9.3   If the condition in Step 9.1 or 9.2 s satisfied, then the audit event  is flagged as aged from the active or inactive workspace.

9.4   If the condition in Step 9.1 or 9.2 is not satisfied, then the audit event is not flagged to be removed from the active or inactive workspace.

 

Updated per IS-604 on 4/23/2003

 

10.0

If an audit event is determined to be aged from the active or inactive workspace, then it is deleted.

 

Alternate flow A1:  Workstation detects a problem.

 

Updated per IS-604 on 4/23/2003

 

11.0

Use case ends

post-conditions

 

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

Variants

Developer note:  details on how this alternate course is handled are recorded in the Complete Daily Workspace Maintenance use case.

 

A1.2

Use case resumes in the step following the exception.

requirement.summary: ACTIVITY: BCI, FMLA-IT (Myla), or HL7 Processing
requirement.description:
[See attachment TTRM814723626171668291.wmf]

 

Figure 8:  UC- BCI Processing

 

This activity describes the information flows through BCI, Myla, or HL7 processing.  There are business rules that describe how information is validated and processed.  In addition, there are business rules that describe how information is applied to the active workspace.  

 

Starting in 05.01, there will be three types of packets possible: one that contains patient information only, one that contains isolate information only, or one that contains both patient and isolate information.  Starting in 08.01, HL7 connectivity is supported.

 

If a packet contains patient and isolate information, the order of processing is:

  • Process patient information first.  The workstation can accept or reject this part of the packet.
  • Process isolate information next.  The workstation can accept or reject this part of the packet.

 

For a packet that contains patient and isolate information, there are three possible outcomes:

 

  • All information in the packet is accepted
  • All information in the packet is rejected
  • A portion of the information in the packet is accepted.

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 Packet for Patient Information
requirement.description:
Name

Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 Packet for Patient Information

Primary actor

Data management system (i.e. LIS or FMLA-IT)

Goal

The Workstation can receive a download message from an LIS or FMLA-IT. The LIS connectivity can be by RS232 or FTP.  HL7 via a network is also supported.   The purpose of this use case is to decode the message, validate it, and then update or create patient and specimen in the system.  

Preconditions
  • Communication between LIS (RS232, FTP, HL7) or FMLA-IT and Workstation established.
  • Packet from the data management system (i.e. LIS or FMLA-IT) has been acknowledged.
  • Packet has been validated as outlined in Validate BCI, FMLA-IT, HL7 Packet use case.

Assumptions
  • Happy path:  both the patient ID and specimen ID (i.e. laboratory identification number) are not found.
  • MULBAT (Multiple batteries per accession number (Sunquest/Cerner) feature is not supported.
  • Specimen ID and laboratory identification number are synonymous.  The term specimen ID is used in BCI documentation to refer to the number assigned to a specimen within the laboratory.
  • Functionality in this use case applies only to the active workspace.  Patient and specimen information is not updated in the inactive workspace.
  • Audit events are captured as a result of processing patient and specimen information.  For details, see the Patient Information Activity or the Search Audit Trail use case.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:444

[REN:PRD:487] [REN:PRD:725]

1.0

This use case begins when the Workstation receives a validated message from the LIS (RS232, FTP or HL7) or FMLA-IT.  In the case of FLMA-IT, Workstation uses the Myla version setting in General Configuration  to know how to process the information.

 

2.0

Workstation determines that the patient and specimen do not already exist in the patient/specimen workspace (contained within the active workspace).  The following checks are made:

 

2.1   The workstation compares the patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 packet with the existing patient IDs in the patient/specimen workspace.  The patient ID is not found in the active workspace.

2.2   The workstation compares the specimen ID (laboratory identification number) in the BCI, FMLA-IT, HL7 packet with the existing laboratory identification numbers in the patient/specimen workspace to find a matching specimen. The laboratory identification number is not found in the active workspace.

2.3   Workstation determines that the alt patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT , or HL7 packet is not associated with a different patient in the active workspace.

Rule:  a "blank" alt patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 packet is not considered a match with a "blank" alt patient ID associated with a different patient in the active workspace.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Alt patient ID is associated with a different patient.

 

 

 

 
  1. Workstation creates a patient and specimen in the patient/specimen workspace using the information in the BCI or FMLA-IT packet.
    1. Workstation creates HL7 OBR information in the HL7 workspace using the information in the HL7 packet.  Information includes:  labId, placerOrderNumber, universalServiceId, serviceIdSystem, serviceName.

 

Rule:  If patient name (RS232 - pn) and/or specimen type (RS232 - ct) are not provided in the BCI, FMLA-IT, HL7 packet, then insert "< >" for these values. (Added per DR-1242 on 10/4/2003; added to make Renaissance have the same functionality as BCI AIX). See Special Requirements for additional details.

 

2.5   If specimen is linked to an isolate, Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.  Updated per DR-1852 on 12/17/2003. [REN:PRD:290]

 

   

Alternate Flow A1:  Either the patient ID is found or the specimen ID is found in the patient/specimen active workspace.

 

 

3.0

Workstation links any existing isolates in the active workspace by executing Link Isolate and Patient Information use case.

 

4.0

If an update occurred to either patient or specimen information, linked isolates in the active workspace are updated.

 

5.0

If ‘Download Isolate’ is enabled in BCI Configuration for BCI Link RS232 or FTP, or if FMLA-IT or HL7 is enabled, the Workstation executes the Process BCI, FMLA-IT, HL7 Packet for Isolate Information use case.

 

 

6.0

The use case ends.

Post-conditions

Validated message routed.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:445

Either the patient ID is found or the specimen ID is found in the patient/specimen active workspace

A1.1

Workstation executes special processing of the BCI, FMLA-IT or HL7 download packet based on the configuration parameter for duplicate demographics.  The Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 Packet for Isolate Information use case may be executed.  See Special Requirements for details.

 

A1.2

As indicated in Special Requirements, use case resumes at Step 3.0 of the main flow or use case ends.

A2

REN:ESPEC:446

Alt patient ID is associated with a different patient

A2.1

Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case.  Renaissance user notified that patient ID XXXX for specimen ID YYYY not updated.  Alt patient ID is associated with patient ID ZZZ.  Use case ends. [REN:PRD:290]

 

A2.2

None

 

 

 

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:447

Update duplicate demographics set to "false" in user configuration:

 

Given which of the following conditions is true, the related action is performed.

 

Condition 1:  Patient and specimen exist

 

Condition 1A: Specimen is linked to patient other than the one defined in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 packet

 

S1   Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case: Renaissance user notified that LIS provide specimen XXXX already exists and is associated with patient YYYY.  Cannot add specimen to patient ZZZZ.  Use case ends

 

Condition 1B: Specimen is linked to the same patient defined in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 packet

 

S2   Patient and specimen information are not updated.

S3   If enabled in BCI Configuration, or if FMLA-IT is enabled, the Workstation executes the Process BCI, FMLA-IT or HL7 Packet for Isolate Information use case.

S4   Use case ends

 

 

 

Condition 2:  Patient exists and specimen does not

 

S5   Workstation creates a specimen in the patient/specimen workspace using the information in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet.  Patient information is not updated. If linked to an isolate, Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.

S6   If enabled in BCI Configuration, or if FMLA-IT is enabled, the Workstation executes the Process BCI,  FMLA-IT Packet, HL7 Packet for Isolate Information use case.

S7   Use case resumes at Step 3 of the Main Flow.

 

 

Condition 3: Patient does not exist and specimen does

 

S8   Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case.  Renaissance user notified that LIS provided specimen XXXX already exists and is associated with patient YYYY.  New patient ZZZZ not created. [REN:PRD:50]

S9   Use case ends.

 

 

Update duplicate demographics set to "true" in user configuration:

 

Given which of the following conditions is true, the related action is performed.

 

Condition 1: Both patient and specimen exist

 

S10   Workstation determines that the alt patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet is not associated with a different patient in the active workspace.

Rule:  a "blank" alt patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet is not considered a match with a "blank" alt patient ID associated with a different patient in the active workspace.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Alt patient ID is associated with a different patient.

 

 

Condition 1A: Specimen is linked to patient other than the one defined in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet

 

S11   Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case: Renaissance user notified that LIS provide specimen XXXX already exists and is associated with patient YYYY.  Cannot add specimen to patient ZZZZ.  Use case ends

 

Condition 1B: Specimen is linked to the same patient defined in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet

 

S12   If alt patient ID is not associated with a different patient, then Workstation updates the specimen information, patient information, if enabled in BCI Configuration, or if FMLA-IT is enabled, the Workstation executes the Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet for Isolate Information use case, and use resumes at Step 3.0 of the Main Flow.  If linked to an isolate, Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.  Updated per DR-1852 on 12/17/2003.

 

 

Condition 2: Patient exists and specimen does not

 

S13   Workstation determines that the alt patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet is not associated with a different patient in the active workspace.

  

Rule:  a "blank" alt patient ID in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet is not considered a match with a "blank" alt patient ID associated with a different patient in the active workspace.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Alt patient ID is associated with a different patient.

 

S14   If alt patient ID is not associated with a different patient, then the Workstation creates a specimen using information from the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet, updates patient information using information from the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet, if enabled in BCI Configuration, or if FMLA-IT is enabled, the Workstation executes the Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet for Isolate Information use case, and use case resumes at Step 3.0 of the main flow.  If linked to an isolate, Workstation logs the event.  For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.  Updated per DR-1852 on 12/17/2003.

 

 

Condition 3: Patient does not exist and specimen does

 

S15   Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case.  Renaissance user notified that LIS provided specimen XXXX already exists and is associated with patient YYYY.  New patient ZZZZ not created. [REN:PRD:50]

S16   Use case ends.

REN:ESPEC:869

Starting in 05.01, there will be 3 types of packets possible.  Starting in 08.01, the system manages test order information for HL7.  Packets include:

  • One that contains patient/specimen information only.  This packet may or may not contain test order information.
  • One that contains isolate information only (organism and offline tests).  This packet may or may not contain test order information.
  • One that contains both patient and isolate information.  This packet may or may not contain test order information.

 

If a packet contains patient/specimen, and isolate information, the order of processing is:

 

  • Process patient/specimen information first.  The workstation can accept or reject this part of the packet.  If the Workstation rejects the patient/specimen, then the system will also reject the test order if this is included in the packet.
  • Process isolate information next.  The workstation can accept or reject this part of the packet.

 

For a packet that contains both patient/specimen and isolate information, there are three possible outcomes:

 

  • All information in the packet is accepted
  • All information in the packet is rejected
  • A portion of the information in the packet is accepted.

REN:ESPEC:870

Download of patient information from FMLA-IT. or HL7 will cause the patient information to be persisted in active workspace.  Download ignores the Patient Demographics flag (whether enabled or disabled).

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 packet with Isolate Information (organism, AST offline test)
requirement.description:
REN:ESPEC:689 Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 Isolate Information Packet (organism, AST offline test) [REN:PRD:495] [REN:PRD:737] [REN:PRD:733] [REN:PRD:734] [REN:PRD:288] [REN:PRD:289] [REN:PRD:725] [REN:PRD:723]

 

Primary actor: Data Management System (i.e. LIS or FMLA-IT)

 

Goal:   The Workstation can receive a download message from an LIS (BCI or HL7), or FMLA-IT.  The purpose of this use case is to decode the message, validate it, and then update or create isolate information.  In 05.01, isolate information includes:  organism ID and AST offline test results.

 

Preconditions

  • Communication between LIS or FMLA-IT and Workstation established.
  • Packet from the data management system (i.e. LIS or FMLA-IT) has been acknowledged.
  • Packet has been validated as outlined in Validate BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet use case.
  • Download Isolate information is enabled in BCI Configuration, or if FMLA-IT is enabled.

 

Post conditions

 

  • Validated message routed

 

Main Flow

 

 

  1. The use case begins when the Workstation receives a validated message from the LIS or FMLA-IT that contains isolate information (i.e. organism ID, AST offline test, etc.). The Workstation uses the Myla version setting in General Configuration  to know how to process the information. NOTE: If patient information is enabled, this use case may also begin when Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet for Patient Information use case completes. ALT (12)
  2. Workstation determines that the Lab ID and Isolate number do not already exist in the isolate download workspace. The following steps are followed:
    1. The workstation compares the Lab ID / isolate number in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet with the existing Lab ID / Isolate numbers in the isolate download workspace to find a match.  The Lab ID / Isolate number is not found in the download isolate workspace. ALT (1)
    2. The workstation creates an isolate in the isolate download workspace using the information in the BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet. See View Isolate Download use case for details.
  3. Workstation then searches the active workspace using the Lab ID and Isolate Number in order to apply organism information from the download. (See Special Requirements for applying organisms to an isolate.) If an isolate is found with no organism and no ID card, then the download organism is applied to the isolate and the isolate is analyzed.
    1. Organism codes sent from an external source are compared to organism codes in the BCI translation table (by link).
    2. Organism matches one of the primary or secondary host codes listed for a bMx code. ALT (10)
  4. If an isolate is found with organism information, the isolate is not updated. ALT (2), ALT (3), ALT (6), ALT (7). ALT (10)
  5. Workstation then searches the active workspace using the Lab ID and Isolate Number in order to apply AST Offline test information from the download. If an isolate is found with no AST offline test, then the AST Offline test is applied to the isolate and the isolate is analyzed. If an isolate is found with an AST offline test, the isolate is not updated.  ALT (4), ALT (5), ALT (8), ALT (11)
  6. If any download isolate information (organism or AST Offline Test) is associated with an isolate in the active workspace, Workstation logs the event with a user of “Download”. For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.
    1. If organism information is associated with an isolate in the active workspace, this information is also available on the Card Detail Report with a user of “Download”
  7. Use case ends.

 

 

 

Alternate Flows / Variations

 

 

  1. REN:ESPEC:690 Lab ID / Isolate number is found in the download workspace.
    1. The workstation ensures that there are no other instances of this lab ID / Isolate number combination, and updates the information in the download isolate workspace with the isolate information in the download packet. [REN:PRD:737]
    2. Use case resumes at step 3 of the Main Flow.
  2. REN:ESPEC:691  Organism in the packet is different from the isolate in the active workspace.
    1. Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case: Renaissance user is notified that the LIS provided isolate information does not match the current isolate in the active workspace.  Information includes:  Lab ID, isolate number, information downloaded, and information found in the active workspace. Isolate in the active workspace is not updated. [REN:PRD:727]
    2. Use case resumes at step 4 of the main flow.
  3. REN:ESPEC:692  Organism in the packet is the same as the isolate in the active workspace.
    1. No action is taken to associate the organism information from the isolate download with the isolate in the active workspace.
    2. Use case resumes at step 4 of the main flow. [REN:PRD:737]

REN:ESPEC:693  AST offline test result in the packet is different from the isolate in the active workspace.

  1. Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case: Renaissance user is notified that the LIS provided isolate information does not match the current isolate in the active workspace.  Information includes:  Lab ID, isolate number, information downloaded, and information found in the active workspace. Isolate in the active workspace is not updated. [REN:PRD:727]
  2. Use case ends.
  • REN:ESPEC:694  AST offline test result in the packet is the same as the isolate in the active workspace.
    1. No action is taken to associate the organism information from the isolate download with the isolate in the active workspace.
    2. Use case resumes at step 5 of the main flow. [REN:PRD:737]
  • REN:ESPEC:695  Workstation searches the active workspace using the Lab ID and Isolate Number, and finds the isolate contains an ID card.
    1. No action is taken to associate the organism ID from the isolate download with the isolate in the active workspace.
    2. AST offline tests may be linked.
    3. Use case ends. [REN:PRD:737]
  • REN:ESPEC:699  Organism in the download packet is inappropriate for the AST card type (i.e. download contains E. coli and the AST card in the active workspace is an AST-GP card)  [REN:PRD:737]
    1. Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case: Renaissance user is notified that the LIS provided isolate information is inappropriate for the AST card type.  Information includes:  Lab ID, isolate number. Isolate in the active workspace is not updated.
    2. The isolate download information is retained, but the download is not a candidate for linking to isolates.
    3. Use case resumes at step 4 of the main flow.
  • REN:ESPEC:700  AST offline test in the download packet is inappropriate for the AST card type (i.e. download contains beta lactamase positive  and the AST card in the active workspace is an AST-GN card)
    1. Workstation sends an alarm following View and Maintain BCI Alarm use case: Renaissance user is notified that the LIS provided isolate information is inappropriate for the AST card type.  Information includes:  Lab ID, isolate number. Isolate in the active workspace is not updated. [REN:PRD:737]
    2. Use case ends.
  • REN:ESPEC:701  Workstation searches the active workspace using the Lab ID and Isolate Number, and finds the more than one instance of the Lab ID / Isolate number in the download workspace.
    1. No action is taken to associate any information from the isolate download with the isolate in the active workspace. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    2. Use case ends.
  • REN:ESPEC:702  Organism in the packet is not known to the workstation.
    1. Add the information to the isolate download workspace, including a description of information we can’t process.
    2. No BCI alarm is generated.
    3. Use case resumes at step 4 of the main flow. [REN:PRD:737] [REN:PRD:725]
  • REN:ESPEC:703  AST offline test in the packet is not known to the workstation.
    1. The isolate is added to the download isolate workspace.  The AST offline test information downloaded is persisted.
    2. No action is taken to associate the AST offline test information from the isolate download with the isolate in the active workspace.
    3. Use case ends. [REN:PRD:737] [REN:PRD:725]
  • REN:ESPEC:798  Patient demographics is enabled, but isolate download was received without patient information.
    1. The downloaded isolate information is applied to the isolate.
    2. Use case resumes at step 2 of the main flow. [REN:PRD:495]

     

    Special Requirements  

     

     

    1. REN:ESPEC:696 BCI alarms generated as a result of organism discrepancies and AST offline test discrepancies for the same isolate are to be combined into a single alarm.  In other words, if both the organism and AST offline test are discrepant, then generate a single alarm for the isolate. [REN:PRD:727]
    2. REN:ESPEC:833 Linking of download isolate information occurs with isolates that only have AST card(s). [REN:PRD:737]
    3. REN:ESPEC:834 Linking of download isolate information occurs with valid data only. [REN:PRD:737]
    4. REN:ESPEC:835 The Workstation will attempt to link valid download isolate information to an isolate a maximum of 5 times. If unable to link after 5 tries, a BCI Alarm is generated. [REN:PRD:737]
    5. REN:ESPEC:840 The Workstation will truncate values in a download using BCI Net in the same manner as for BCI-RS232.  Rules are as follows: [REN:PRD:495]
      1. All "Numeric" type fields, (those only expected to contain numbers like Isolate Number, Relative Record Numbers, etc.), are RIGHT Justified and LEFT Truncated.
        1. Example:  Isolate Number:  |t10003| becomes '03' or just plain '3' after Truncating the Left '00'.
      2. All Alpha and Alphanumeric type fields, (like Patient ID, Patient Name, and just about all the rest), are LEFT Justified and RIGHT Truncated.
        1. Example:  Patient Name:  |pnJingleheimer-Schmidt, John Jacob My Name Too| becomes 'Jingleheimer-Schmidt, John Jacob My Name' after Truncating the Right ' Too'.
      3. Lab ID is Alphanumeric, but is treated like a Numeric, so it is RIGHT Justified and LEFT Truncated because the significant and unique digits are (usually) to the Right.
        1. Example:  Lab ID: |ciQuest2009September22a123456| becomes '09September22a123456' after truncating the Left 'Quest20'.
      4. Spaces will be trimmed (from the right or left).  
      5. The system will remove leading zeros from the isolate number.

     

    REN:ESPEC:850

    The following table provides a condensed view of validations in different situations, and the expected actions by the Workstation.  [REN:PRD:495]

    NOTE:  The Demographic setting does not have an impact on this table.
