requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Validate BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7 packet
requirement.description:
Name

Validate BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet

Primary actor

Data management system (i.e. LIS)

Goal

The Workstation can receive a download message from an LIS.  The purpose of this use case is to decode the message, validate it, and send it on to the Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet use case functionality.

 

A description of the BCI protocol can be found in Bidirectional Computer Interface Specification for bioLIAISON.

 

Preconditions
  • Communication between LIS and Workstation Established
  • Packet from the data management system (i.e. LIS) has been acknowledged

Assumptions
  • Audit events are captured as a result of processing patient, specimen, and isolate information.  For details, see the Patient Information Activity or the Search Audit Trail use case.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:438

[REN:PRD:487]

[REN:PRD:725]

1.0

This use case begins when the Workstation receives a marshaled message from an LIS in the standard pipe-delimited format (RS232), XML format (FTP), or XML expanded format (FMLA-IT, and HL7).

 

 

 

 

2.0

The workstation parses the message and converts into native format (validates message).

 

 

 

Alternate Flow A1:  invalid character encoding

 

 

Alternate Flow A2:  required field missing

Alternate Flow A3:  unexpected field

Alternate Flow A4:  field formatting error

Alternate Flow A5:  fatal processing error

Alternate Flow A8:  invalid for HL7 processing

 

 

Removed per BCI review on 6/11/2003

 

3.0

The workstation validates the isolate number.

3.1   Isolate number is a max of 2 characters

   3.1.1   The truncation of the isolate number will be from the left (same

      as lab ID).

3.2   Leading zeros will be removed from the isolate number. [REN:PRD:725]

 

4.0

The workstation determines (if isolate download is enabled in BCI Config, or if FMLA-IT is enabled) that the packet is considered to be an isolate download packet if it contains any of the following fields: isolate number (RS232, t1), organism code (RS232, o1), organism name (RS232,o2), AST offline test code (RS232,b1), AST offline test name (RS232,b2),AST offline test result (RS232,b3).

 

4.1   If isolate number (RS232 - t1) is present and valid, the packet is saved and is a candidate for linking to an isolate.

4.2   If isolate number (RS232 - t1) is present and valid and organism code (RS232 - o1) is present and valid- the packet is saved and is a candidate for linking  [REN:PRD:495]

 

See Special Requirements for additional validation rules.

 

5.0

The workstation ensures that for isolate download processing, the packet must have:

  1. An isolate number (if the packet has any other isolate information, like organism code, AST Offline test code).
  2. Packet must contain an organism known to the system. If not, save for later display.
  3. An organism code (if it has an organism name)
  4. An AST offline test code (if AST offline test name is downloaded).
  5. An AST offline test result code (if AST offline test result name is downloaded).

 

Alternate Flow A6:  Packet does not have isolate information required for processing

 

Rule:  AST Offline test code and result are not required.

 

Rule:  The matching of isolate download information to BCI translation codes (host or BMX) is case sensitive.  [REN:PRD:495] [REN:PRD:737]

 

 

6.0

Workstation continues to process the validated BCI or FMLA-IT message by executing Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet for Patient Information use case if ‘Patient demographics’ is enabled.

 

Alternate Flow A7: ‘Patient demographics’ is not enabled.

 

7.0

Use case ends

post-conditions

System ready to receive next message.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:439

Invalid character encoding

A1.1

System Issues a BCI alarm with message:

  • “Current character encoding [encoding name] is incompatible with received message on link [link name] for message: [message]”

 

Developer Note: the message displayed will likely be undecipherable by most users.  It may be useful to product support.

 

A1.2

Use case ends

A2

REN:ESPEC:440

Required

field missing

 

A2.1

System Issues a BCI alarm with message:

  • “Required field [field name] missing from message received on link [link name] for message: [message]”

 

Rule:  patient name (RS232 - pn) is not a required download field.

Rule:  specimen type (RS232 - ct) is not a required download field.

(Added per DR-1242 0n 10/4/2003; added to make Renaissance have the same functionality as BCI AIX)

 

Developer Note: the message displayed will be in pipe-delimited format for BCI-RS232. XML messages are too large to display from BCI Net or FMLA-IT.  For XML, the number of characters is limited to 20.

 

A2.2

Use case ends

A3

REN:ESPEC:441

Unexpected field

A3.1

If BCI Link (RS232), System issues an alarm with the following message:

  • “Field [field name] encountered in Download message at improper location for message: [message]”

If BCI Link (FTP) or FMLA-IT, System issues an alarm with information describing the problem.

 

A3.2

Use case ends.

A4

REN:ESPEC:442

Field formatting error

A4.1

System issues a BCI alarm with one of the following messages:

  • BCI Download field [field name] with value [field value] and length [actual length] exceeds maximum length of [max length]. (Removed per DR-915 on 8/22/2003.  An incorrect field length should not generate an alarm.  Errors in field lengths are handled this way in BCI for AIX.)
  • Invalid date field in BCI Download message for field [field name] with value [field value], expected format=[date format].  When an invalid date is detected, date field is set to "current date and current time", and the packet continues processing. (Added per DR-915 on 8/23/2003.  This makes Renaissance implementation the same as BCI- AIX).
  • Invalid numeric value for BCI Download field [field name], value = [field value]. Removed per BCI review on 6/11/2003
  • In the BCI Link (FTP) file, one or more fields contains a pipe (|) character
  • Invalid isolate number field (zero (0)) in a download message from [system] (where system = BCI Link (RS232, or FTP),  or FMLA-IT) [REN:PRD:495] [REN:PRD:725] [REN:PRD:727]

 

A4.2

Use Case ends

A5

REN:ESPEC:443

fatal processing error

A5.1

System issues a BCI alarm with the following message:

  • Fatal error handling download message [message] on link [link name].

 

A5.2

Use Case ends

 

 

Removed per BCI review on 6/11/2003

A6

REN:ESPEC:686

Packet does not have isolate information required for processing

A6.1

System issues a BCI alarm with the following message:

  • “Required field [field name] missing from message received on link [link name].”[REN:PRD:495]

System discards the isolate download packet.

Use case ends.

A7

REN:ESPEC:687

Patient demographics not enabled

A7.1

Workstation continues to process the validated BCI or FMLA-IT message by executing Process BCI, FMLA-IT, or HL7  packet for Isolate Information use case.

 

A7.2

Use case ends.

A8

REN:ESPEC:988

Invalid for HL7 processing

A8.1

System Issues a BCI alarm with message:

  • HL7 message received is not valid.  Message rejected and sender notified.

 

 

A8.2

Packet is rejected and LIS notified

 

A8.3

Use case ends

 

 

Special Requirements

 

REN:ESPEC:847

 

 

 

Logic and validation rules for organism include:

 

Patient information:  enabled or disabled

Isolate download:  enabled

 

The packet is considered to be an isolate download packet if it contains any of the following fields: isolate number (RS232, t1), organism code (RS232, o1), organism name (RS232, o2), AST offline test code (RS232, b1), AST offline test name (RS232, b2),AST offline test result (RS232, b3).

 

1.  Inspect the BCI download packet and determine if it contains isolate download information.  If it is found to be an isolate download, the following apply:

 

a.  Isolate number (t1) is missing:  BCI alarm and discard isolate info in the packet, else

b.  Organism code (o1) is missing- no alarm and save

c. Isolate number (t1) is there and valid- save packet and candidate for linking

d.  Isolate number (t1) is there and not valid- BCI alarm and discard packet

e.  Isolate number (t1) valid + Organism code (o1) is there and valid- save, candidate for linking

f.   Isolate number (t1) valid + organism code (o1) is there and not valid (field missing, org not known to Ren, org is blank)- save, not a candidate for linking

g.  If we get an org name or AST offline test name, we do not care.  We do our matching on code.  We just display the name in the display download information.  Not a candidate for linking.  [REN:PRD:495]

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Send Data to LIS, FMLA-IT (Myla), or HL7
requirement.description:
Name

Send Data to LIS, FMLA (Myla), or HL7

Primary actor

Lab Tech (Local or remote) or Renaissance Application (Workstation)

Goal

The Workstation can send an upload message to a Laboratory Information System (LIS) or external data management system (i.e. Thera Trac 2, OBSERVA, Myla).  The purpose of this use case is to encode the message and send it on to external computer system.  This action can be initiated as a result of analysis completing (Workstation is the primary actor), or at the request of the Lab Tech (View and Maintain Test Result use case).

 

A description of the BCI protocol can be found in Bidirectional Computer Interface Specification for bioLIAISON [R5].

 

Preconditions
  • BCI installed and configured or FMLA-IT enabled
  • Communication between external data management system and Workstation established.
  • For an isolate to be sent to an external data management system (i.e. LIS), the following must be true:  isolate is not "qualified", isolate is "final" or “preliminary”, isolate does not need to be "reviewed", isolate does not need to be "approved".  See Analyze Isolate Data use case for details.

Assumptions
  • None

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:448

[REN:PRD:487]

1.0

This use case begins when a subsystem requests an upload of a valid isolate (i.e.: not qualified, final, preliminary, not needing review, not needing approval) to a Laboratory Information System (LIS) or other external data management system.  This may be based on user (local or remote) input or automatically performed when an isolate attains a given state (termed “auto transfer”).  For automatic transfer, see Analyze Isolate Data use case. [REN:PRD:718] [REN:PRD:723] [REN:PRD:700]

 

2.0

Workstation creates the upload packet following configuration parameters for upload and drug suppression. AST cards that are 64 well or 104 well are supported.

 

Alternate Flow A2:  Workstation creates the upload packet for BCI Link (FTP)

Alternate Flow A3:  Workstation creates the upload packet for FMLA-IT.

Alternate Flow A5:  Workstation creates the upload packet for HL7.

 

 

Rule: If FMLA-IT is enabled, all information available is sent, except if the Patient Demographics flag in General Configuration is disabled.  If disabled, patient information will not be sent to FMLA-IT. [REN:PRD:725]

 

Rule: If FMLA-IT is enabled, isolate results are sent for the first time when an isolate is complete "green square".  Results are sent again when the isolate state moves backward (i.e. complete to qualified and back to complete). [REN:PRD:725]

 

 

Rule: If FMLA-IT is enabled, isolate status is sent with each isolate state change.  The state change can be forward (i.e. preliminary to complete) or can be backward (green square to qualified).  [REN:PRD:725]

 

 

2.0

Conditions include the following:

 

2.1   If the isolate contains an AST card, AST test results are filtered to remove tests used to detect resistance mechanisms that have been disabled by the Lab Supervisor in upload configuration.  (For example, if beta lactamase is disabled in upload configuration, then this test and result will not be included in the BCI packet).

2.2   If the isolate contains an AST card, and the Lab Supervisor has disabled sending of deduced drugs, AST test results are filtered to remove deduced drugs and results.

2.3   If the isolate contains an AST card, and the Lab Supervisor has disabled sending “disabled with comments”, AST test results and associated comments are filtered to remove these drugs and results.  

2.4   If the isolate contains an AST card, and the Lab Supervisor has enabled sending “disabled with comments”, AST test results and associated comments are sent based on user configuration.  

2.5   If the isolate contains an AST card and the AES confidence for the isolate is either CONSISTENT or CORRECTED, include the tested antibiotic families and all detected phenotypes (wild, acquired resistance, and natural resistance) in the BCI upload packet.  In other words, if the AES confidence for an isolate is INCONSISTENT, then do not include antibiotic families or phenotypes for the isolate in the BCI packet. (Updated following ESPEC review held on 6/6/2003)

2.6   If the isolate contains an AST card and configuration option is disabled to send suppressed antibiotics, then remove any suppressed antibiotics as configured by the Lab Supervisor.  See Customize AST Configuration Parameters use case for details. [REN:PRD:498]

 

 

 

2.7   If the isolate contains an AST card, then remove any suppressed antibiotics done at the request of the Lab Tech.  See View and Maintain Test Results use case for details.

2.8   Drug and Organism codes are translated according to Lab Supervisor configuration for the given link.

2.9   Remaining data is mapped to BCI fields according to the user options for field length, date format, and leading zeros.  See Customize Upload Parameters use case for specific information.

2.10   Fields disabled for upload by the Lab Supervisor are removed from the BCI upload packet.

2.11   Fields that do not contain data are removed from the BCI upload packet.  (Added per DR-1220 on 10/4/2003)

2.12   Case of entire message is changed as needed to comply with Lab Supervisor configuration of  “Case of Data” setting.

 

 

 

2.13   If limited patient demographics in user configuration is disabled, then send the current date as the patient hospital number (i.e. "pi" field). (RS232 only). If the Patient demographics’ flag is disabled, the workstation will still send any patient information available via BCI Link (RS232).

2.14    If the isolate contains an AST card and configuration option is disabled to send suppressed MICs, then remove any suppressed MICs as configured by the Lab Supervisor.  See Customize AST Configuration Parameters use case for details. [REN:PRD:717]

2.15   If the isolate contains an AST card and configuration option is enabled to send suppressed MICs, then do not remove any suppressed MICs as configured by the Lab Supervisor.  See Customize AST Configuration Parameters use case for details. [REN:PRD:717]

2.16   If the isolate contains an AST card and configuration option is enabled to send suppressed MICs with a flag, then do not remove any suppressed MICs as configured by the Lab Supervisor.  Include a flag to indicate that the MIC was suppressed in the Ren system.  See Customize AST Configuration Parameters use case for details. [REN:PRD:717]

2.17   If the isolate has user-entered breakpoints by infection site, the system will send that antibiotic’s unique bMx code or host code in the BCI packet. [REN:PRD:719]

2.18   Card information is grouped within the BCI packet (RS-232 or FTP).  Information includes:  Expiration Date, Lot Number, Disposable Type, Card bar code (identifier of the disposable), Final Date and Time (results date and time), Start Date and Time, and User ID and User Name (Setup Tech).  If the isolate contains multiple AST cards, then this information is grouped by card type. [REN:PRD:259]

2.19   If ‘Multiple Host Codes’ is enabled in BCI config, the workstation can send (via RS232 or FTP) the packet to the LIS or external data management system.  Organism rules follow:

2.19.1   If the user selected an organism (keyid) or used our ID card, we send the primary code.

2.19.2   If the workstation received the organism from the LIS, then the Workstation will send back their code (if defined to the link).  

a. The code sent back must be a valid organism code.  

b. The LIS code must be translated in either the primary or secondary columns in organism translation.

c. All of this is done by link.  The workstation will send back their code, if their code is defined to the link.  If a link is enabled and their code is not defined, then we will send our primary (host) code or bMx code.

2.19.3   If the user selected an organism (keyid) over the download code, we send the organism primary code.

2.10   Starting in 08.01, McFarland information is sent based on user configuration for RS232 packets.

 

Rule:   A packet can be created and sent, following a non-destructive update, if an organism or antibiotic has been deleted from the current knowledgebase. [REN:PRD:719]

 

Rule:   Isolates that contain a terminated card (either a terminated ID or AST card) are not to be sent via BCI to external data management systems.  (Added per DR-3577 on 9/6/2005)  

 

 

 

 

 

Rule:   If an antibiotic is suppressed (by user action or bioART) with a suppressed MIC, and send suppressed drug is disabled in BCI config, and then the system will never send an MIC without drug information to an LIS. [REN:PRD:717]

 

Rule:   BCI packets with send suppress enabled and send disable with comment disabled.  An isolate is both "suppressed" and "disable with comment". The drug (which is both suppressed and disabled with comment) is not sent in the BCI RS232 packet.

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled; suppressed MICs are sent with a flag indicating suppression.

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled; antibiotics flagged as “disabled with comment” by bioART are sent with a flag indicating disabled with comment.

 

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled: deduced antibiotics are sent with a flag indicating it is deduced.

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled; Suppressed test/antibiotic is sent with a flag indicated it was suppressed.

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled, all tests, including beta-lactamase are sent.

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled, preliminary results are sent.

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled, new fields added in Release 05.01 are included (e.g.: bar code, expiration date, lot number, etc.) [REN:PRD:725]

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled, new fields added in Release 07.01 are included (e.g.: comment code, comment text, antibiotic flag for disabled with comment)

 

Rule:   If FMLA-IT is enabled, an MIC is sent to Myla for antibiotics with an interpretation of “IE”.  An MIC is not sent in the case of a (-).

 

Rule:   For RS232, an MIC is sent to Myla for antibiotics with an interpretation of “IE” and an MIC of “(-)” if the drugs has an interpretation of (-).

 

Rule:   There are special rules for the processing of organism quantity to FMLA-IT (Myla).  Please see special requirement for details.

 

Rule:   Starting in 08.01, McFarland information is to be sent to Myla.

 

 

 

3.0

Message is converted to configured character encoding.

 

Alternate Flow A1:  Invalid character encoding

 

4.0

Message is queued for sending to LIS as soon as possible. [REN:PRD:490] [REN:PRD:491] [REN:PRD:490] [REN:PRD:507]

 

Alternate Flow A4:  Unable to send packet to FMLA-IT or HL7  connector

 

Developer note:  per the PRD, queued transactions are to be available to be sent to the LIS for at least 1 week.

 

5.0

Use case ends

post-conditions

BCI upload packet created and ready to be sent to external data management system.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:449

invalid character encoding

A1.1

System Issues a BCI alarm with message:

  • “Current character encoding [encoding name] is incompatible with Upload message on link [link name] for message: [message]”

 

Developer Note:  the message displayed will be in pipe-delimited format.

 

A1.2

Use case ends

A2

REN:ESPEC:719

Workstation creates the upload packet for BCI LINK (FTP)

A2.1

Packet is created in compliance with V2S-COMSPEC-013.doc and sent in xml format if BCI FTP is enabled.  AST cards that are 64 well or 104 well are supported.

  [REN:PRD:720] .  [REN:PRD:717]

 

Developer and testers note: Two packets are sent – one for ID and one for AST when the isolate group contains both. This matches RS232 implementation.

 

Rule:  Workstation will not send “fake” patient information (like the current date for the pi field.  [REN:PRD:259]

 

Rule:   In release 07.01, the BCI FTP packet contains bioART coded comments, both text and comment code.

 

Rule:   BCI packets with send suppress enabled and send disable with comment disabled.  An isolate is both "suppressed" and "disable with comment". The drug (which is both suppressed and disabled with comment) is not sent in the BCI RS232 packet.

 

Rule:   For FTP, an MIC is sent to Myla for antibiotics with an interpretation of “IE” and an MIC of “(-)” if the drugs has an interpretation of (-).

 

 

 

A2.2

Use case resumes in step 2 of main flow.

A3

REN:ESPEC:819

Workstation creates the upload packet for FMLA-IT

A3.1

Packet is created and sent in .xml format if FMLA-IT is enabled. The format and content of the XML message is based on user configuration in General Configuration.  Once FMLA-IT is enabled, no further upload packets are created or download packets are persisted for BCI Link (RS232 or FTP)

 

Rule:  Information in the packet is similar to a packet for RS232 or FTP (antibiotic, MICs, interpretations, phenotypes, organism ID, % probability, etc.)

1.  Deduced antibiotics are sent, with a flag indicating it is deduced.

2.  Suppressed MICs are sent, with a flag indicating suppressed

3.  Suppressed test/antibiotic are sent, with a flag indicating suppressed

4.  All tests are sent, including beta lactamase

5.  Preliminary results are sent

6.  New fields added in 05.01 (bar code, expiration date, etc.) are sent.

7.  New fields added in 07.01 (bioART comment code, bioART comment text, “disable with comment” flag, etc.).

8.  Isolates analyzed with the “>” convention are sent to Myla.

[REN:PRD:752] [REN:PRD:753]

 

Alternate Flow A4: Unable to send packet to FMLA-IT

 

A3.2

Use case resumes in step 2 of main flow

A4

REN:ESPEC:820

Unable to send packet to FMLA-IT or HL7 connector

A4.1

Workstation is unable to send a packet to the FMLA-IT or HL7 connector built inside of VITEK 2 Systems. If the packet cannot be sent, it is added to a queue and sent when the connection is reestablished.

 

A4.2

The VITEK 2 system will generate a BCI (i.e.: communication) Alarm indicating that the FMLA-IT or HL7 packet was not sent (message is dropped). [REN:PRD:720]

 

A4.2

Use case ends.

 

A5

REN:ESPEC:989

Workstation creates upload packet for HL7

A5.1

Packet is created and sent in .xml format to Mirth if HL7  is enabled. The format and content of the XML message is based on user configuration in General Configuration.  Once HL7 is enabled, no further upload packets are created or download packets are persisted for BCI Link (RS232 or FTP) or Myla.

 

Rule:  Information in the packet is similar to a packet for RS232 or FTP (antibiotic, MICs, interpretations, phenotypes, organism ID, % probability, etc.)

 

Rule:  if a HL7 mapping code (organism or antibiotic) could not be found in the system, then send the default bioMerieux code instead.  If the default code could not be found, then send the internal bioMerieux code.  In all cases, generate a communication alarm to alert the lab.

 

1.  Deduced antibiotics are sent, with a flag indicating it is deduced.

2.  Suppressed MICs are sent, with a flag indicating suppressed

3.  Suppressed test/antibiotic are sent, with a flag indicating suppressed

4.  All tests are sent, including beta lactamase

5.  Preliminary results are sent

6.  New fields added in 05.01 (bar code, expiration date, etc.) are sent.

7.  New fields added in 07.01 (bioART comment code, bioART comment text, “disable with comment” flag, etc.).

8.  New fields added in 08.01 are sent (McFarland and McFarland range)

9.  Isolates analyzed with the “>” convention are sent to HL7.

 

Alternate Flow A4: Unable to send packet to FMLA-IT or HL7

 

 

A5.2

Mirth converts the XML packet to HL7 format and sends this to the LIS.

 

 

A5.3

Use case resumes in step 2 of main flow

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:921

 

Business rules around the Myla interface and the processing of organism quantity

 

  1. If the isolate contains a predefined organism quantity code and text that matches bioMerieux’s reference knowledge, then the organism quantity  code and text  is sent to Myla.  Myla will pass this information to an LIS via BCI Link.

    2.  

  2. If the isolate contains a predefined organism quantity code and the text does not match bioMerieux’s reference knowledge text, then the organism quantity  code and text  is not sent to Myla.  No alert or warning is generated on VITEK 2 Systems.  Organism quantity information is not sent to an LIS via BCI link.

    3.  

  3. If the isolate contains a custom organism quantity code and text, then the organism quantity  code and text  is sent to Myla.  Myla will map any custom organism quantity to a reference knowledge code of “unknown”.   “Unknown” is sent to an LIS via BCI link.

 

 

 

This truth table below was added to help clarify how this use case (creation of BCI packet) and the BCI configuration use case interact in relation to suppress antibiotic and suppress chart report MIC.

Name

Schedule automatic backup

Primary actor

Lab Supervisor

Goal

Allow the Lab Supervisor to define the time an unattended backup will occur and the frequency of the backup.

Preconditions
  • Lab Supervisor has logged onto the Renaissance application and navigated to the utilities workspace.

Assumptions

Trigger

The Lab Supervisor elects to define the schedule for automatic backup.

Description

Step

Action

The use case begins when the Lab Supervisor elects to schedule Renaissance backup. [REN:PRD:438]

 

2.0

Workstation displays the schedule backup workspace.  Information includes:

2.2   Hour of backup (integer, hour, range:  0-23; default 0300)

2.4   Print backup status (enable/disable; default:  enabled)

Rule:  If changes are made, Lab Supervisor must either save or cancel changes before Workstation allows application navigation.

 

A1.2

requirement.description:
Name

Initiate version verification

Primary actor

A non-human actor (system use case)

Goal

To ensure that the installed version of the Renaissance Application contains a cohesive set of versioned components that are each compatible with each other.  If any components fail verification, the Renaissance system as a whole is to be considered invalid.

Preconditions
  • Renaissance has been loaded and services are functional.

Assumptions
  • None

Trigger

There can be multiple triggers for this system use case.  They include:

 

  • Execution of end of day processing activity.  This use case is executed prior to executing unattended daily backup.  See End of Day Processing use case for details.
  • Workstation reboot with the subsequent starting of Renaissance services
  • Renaissance user launching the Renaissance Client by executing Start Renaissance Application use case.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:465

1.0

Use case starts when some component of Renaissance initiates a request to have the system verified.

 

2.0

Workstation determines that all installed components pass their verification test.  The following are verified: [REN:PRD:435] [REN:PRD:538] [REN:PRD:539]

 

File integrity

 

2.1   Installed application JAR files (programs and reports).

2.2   Database schema

2.3   Third party tools

   2.3.1   Pepito

   2.3.2   Fast Objects

   2.3.3   Viso Broker

   2.3.4   GUI widgets (i.e. calendar tool for date entry)

 

Knowledgebases

 

2.4   Identification

2.5   Susceptibility

2.6   Advanced Expert (AES)

2.7   Bi-directional Computer Interface (BCI)

 

Alternate Flow A1: One or more components fails verification

 

 

3.0

Workstation determines that a knowledge base update (DOU) completed.

 

Developer note:  a marker file could be used to let Core know if a knowledge base update did not complete.  If the marker file were present, Core would know that the Poet and Postgres KBs are not in sync.

 

Alternate Flow A2: Knowledge base update (DOU) did not complete

 

 

4.0

Use case ends

post-conditions
  • All versioned components have been verified without errors or exceptions.

Exceptions

Step

Exception

Branching Action

N/A

N/A

N/A

N/A

Variations

Step

Variants

A1

REN:ESPEC:466

One or more component fails verification

A1.1

An event is logged to the Windows Event Log representing details about the failure.  Details should include the following:

 

A1.1.1   Component that failed verification

A1.1.2   Subcomponent that caused failure if applicable (detail the finest level of granularity possible)

A1.2.3   Any pertinent troubleshooting data (i.e. expected checksum and actual checksum)

 

A1.2

Workstation displays a modal dialog box with the following information:

 

A1.2.1   Information outlined in step A1.1.

A1.2.2   Information for the user that the internal version verification has failed, and the user should contact a bioMerieux support representative for assistance.

 

 

 

 

A1.3

Renaissance user acknowledges the information.

 

A1.4

Any Renaissance components that are currently registered to Shutdown Monitor are stopped by the Workstation, except the Shutdown Monitor service.  

 

Developer note:  The system should enter a state that will prevent components from coming back up until the version verification failure has been resolved.  The entire system must pass version verification before it is eligible to run. Implementation will likely call for an exception.  The process responsible for version verification may be left running in order to support appropriate notification to the user if an attempt is made to start the Renaissance client, for example.

 

 

A1.5

Use case ends

A2

REN:ESPEC:654

Knowledge base update (DOU) did not complete

 

A2.1

Workstation determined that a knowledge base update (DOU) did not complete.  This could be determined by the presence of a marker file.

 

A2.2

Workstation does not allow a user to open the VITEK 2 Systems application.  Workstation documents this in the Core log files.  The log entry indicates why a user was not permitted to open the VITEK 2 Systems application (KB updated failed to complete).

 

Developer note:  informing Shutdown Monitor and not allowing Core to start is one option to prevent the client from starting.

 

A2.3

Use case ends.

Special Requirements

None

Primary actor

Renaissance Timer

Goal

At specified intervals, test communication with all Instruments attached to the Workstation to verify Instrument communication.  If communication fails, alert the user.

Preconditions
  • Renaissance services are running
  • One or more Instruments are attached to the Workstation and communication has been established.

Assumptions
  • Each attached Instrument will "ping" the Workstation at regular intervals to test communication lines.  This function is executed as part of the Instrument firmware.

Trigger

At a specified interval, verify Instrument communication.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:460

1.0

This use case begins when the Renaissance Timer verifies the connection status of all Instruments defined to the Workstation.  The interval between connection verification attempts is not to exceed 1 minute.  [REN:PRD:537]

 

2.0

Workstation detects communication with all defined Instruments.

 

Alternate Flow A1:Connection verification fails for one or more Instruments

 

Developer note:  it is not required to persist the Instrument status with each attempt to verify the connection.  This would quickly overrun the Monthly Instrument Status log.  The purpose of this use case is to make sure there is communication between the Instrument and Workstation.  Instrument status does not need to be persisted.

 

Developer note:  one option to implement this requirement would be to utilized the Renaissance Device Communication Service.

 

 

3.0

Use case ends

A1.2

Workstation documents the problem along with its description, and is recorded as a Renaissance alarm.  This alarm is displayed to the current user or next Renaissance user to log onto Renaissance following View and Maintain Alarms use case.

Name

Send isolates to AES

Primary actor

None (Abstract use case)

Goal

Apply business rules related to sending isolate information to Advanced Expert for validation and interpretation.

Preconditions
  • Isolate can be final or preliminary
  • Isolate group contains at least one AST card and is not Quality Control.
  • Isolate is not qualified.

Assumptions
  • Queued AES questions are automatically sent for validation and interpretation when Advanced Expert indicates it is once again ready to perform expertise.

Trigger

Isolate is ready for validation and interpretation.

Description

Step

Action

REN:ESPEC:467

1.0

Workstation determines that the isolate is ready for validation and interpretation. [REN:PRD:185] [REN:PRD:186]

 

Alternate Flow A1:  All drugs are disclaimed

Alternate Flow A2:  All drugs are terminated

Alternate Flow A3:  Organism associated with the isolate is a "slashline" or "organism group" and not claimed by Advanced Expert.

Alternate Flow A4:  Organism associated with the isolate is a yeast

Alternate Flow A6:  One or more drugs are disclaimed but not all

Alternate Flow A7:  One or more drugs are terminated but not all

Alternate Flow A8:  One or more drugs are terminated but not all and the isolate is preliminary

 

 

2.0

Workstation creates the AES question.  Information includes:

 

2.1   Organism associated with the isolate

2.2   Tested antibiotics for all AST cards in the isolate group

2.3   If the isolate is final, MIC values for all tested antibiotics.  If the isolate is preliminary:

2.3.1 and the AST Configuration is enabled for ‘Preliminary Results by antibiotic family’, all antibiotics are included if each antibiotic in an antibiotic family are also final. [REN:PRD:718]

2.3.2 and the AST Configuration is enabled for ‘Preliminary Results by antibiotic’, the Workstation creates the AES question with biologic validation disabled. [REN:PRD:721]

 

Developer note:  see ALT6 and ALT 7 for special processing of disclaimed and terminated antibiotics.

 

2.4   Tests for resistance mechanisms and results performed on the card

2.5   Tests for resistance mechanisms and results entered by the Lab Tech

2.6   List of antibiotics that are candidates for deduction for the card types in the isolate group

2.7   List of analysis parameters to be used for validation and interpretation (Developer note:  this is optional information.  If no parameters are supplied in the question, AES will apply the current parameters settings defined in the active parameter set)

 

Developer note:  suppressed antibiotic-organism combinations defined in configuration or established by the Lab Tech are sent to AES.

 

 

3.0

Workstation sends question to AES for validation and interpretation, including any queued questions.

 

Alternate Flow A5:  AES Question cannot be sent for validation and interpretation

 

Developer note: if the Lab Supervisor is editing an AES configuration parameter set, expertise is not permitted.

 

 

4.0

Use case ends.

Name

Primary actor

None (Abstract use case)

Goal

Preconditions

Assumptions

Description

Step

Action

3.9   Detected changes to tests of resistance mechanisms (if any)

For specific display rules, please see the detailed table at the end of this use case.

Special Requirements

REN:ESPEC:482

See below

 

This is a summary of possible results from an AES answer, and what the Workstation will do in each case.  This summarizes information contained in View Detailed Drug Result use case with respect to the processing of an AES answer.  Table revised as a result of DR-1787 on 12/23/2003.  Table was revised on 1/15/2004 because of the design decision to hide an MIC for an organism-antibiotic combination with no breakpoints defined in the active parameter set.  The Table was revised again on 10/8/2004 for DR-2945 related to deduced antibiotics that span category calls.  The rules were updated on 11/21/2005 in to clarify the rules and to make adjustments for forcing to susceptible.  Eve Lazzarni, Carole Shubert, and Butch Schleicher updated rules.

 

General Rules:

  1. If the AES confidence is consistent or consistent with corrections, the Workstation displays the "Final Forced Interpreted" interpretation result in isolate view.  In essence, the Workstation displays the expertized interpretation result.
  2. If the AES confidence is inconsistent or expertise not performed, the Workstation displays the "Forced Observed" interpretation result in isolate view. In essence, the Workstation displays the forced observed (instrument) interpretation result.
  3. Because of a change made by CLSI for the implementation of a new test, it is now possible for an antibiotic interpretation to be forced to either resistant or susceptible.
  4. The correction pop-up displayed in isolate view displays both the observed and expertized interpretation.  For example, "Interpretation changed from "S" to "I" ".
  5. MIC values are to be displayed with an interpretations of “IE”.
  6. MIC values are not to be displayed with an interpretations of “(-)”.  It is acceptable to display a “(-)“ instead of an MIC value.

    7.  

    Rules to display interpretation ranges as single category calls:

    Tested antibiotics:

  7. If both the observed result and the expertized result (Final Forced Interpreted) are ranges (S/I, I/R, or S/I/R), display "blank" for the interpretation in isolate view. (This rule was created to handle the amox1 and amox2 issue.)
  8. If the observed result is a range (S/I, I/R, or S/I/R) and the expertized result (Final Forced Interpreted) is a single category call (for example R), display the expertized result. (New rule to avoid displaying blank when AES proposes a single category call.)
  9. If the observed result is a single category call and the expertized result is a range (S/I, I/R, or S/I/R), display the category call of this range closest to the observed result. (Regardless of whether the expertized result comes from an MIC correction or a therapeutic correction, we take the category call closest to the observed result.  (This rule was initially added per DR-3082 on 10/8/2004 as part of the 1.02 project.  This rule was revised on 11/28/2005 in order to clarify and consolidate rules.)

Deduced antibiotics (phenotypic):

 

  1. If the deduced result is a range that includes S (for example S/I or S/I/R), display blank for the interpretation in isolate view.
  2. If the deduced result is a range that does not include S (for example I/R), display the most resistant category call of this range for the interpretation in isolate view. (i.e. R in this example).  Added per DR-2945 on 10/8/2004 as part of the 1.02 project.

    3.  

     

     

    Display of deduced antibiotics by breakpoint category:

  3. Do not display a deduced drug by breakpoint category if the antibiotic being deduced does not have breakpoints by breakpoint category.  For example, do not display deductions like +Gatifloxacin (meningitis) "S" and +Gatifloxacin (other) "S". Only display  +Gatifloxacin "S".  Added per DR-3022 on 10/8/204 as part of the Renaissance 1.02 project.
  4. Display breakpoint category for a deduced antibiotic, if that antibiotic has multiple breakpoint categories defined in the active parameter set.  For example, in EUCAST meropenem has multiple breakpoint categories (meningitis and other).  If this antibiotic can be deduced, and no other business rules are violated, the Workstation would display a deduction for breakpoint categories defined for the deduced antibiotic.
  5. In release 05.01 because of the addition of new breakpoint categories, a new step was added to deductions.  At the end deductions (equivalent, phenotypic, or equivalent + phenotypic), the Workstation will attempt to merge deduction results.  If the merge is successful, a single deduction is displayed.  If the merge fails, no deduction is displayed.  The merge will fail if:
    1. A deduced interpretation spans categories (S/R, etc.)
    2. The interpretations are different between breakpoint categories.
    3. If an equivalency rule is successful for one breakpoint category, but not successful for another.

Rules dealing with an organism-antibiotic combination without any breakpoints defined (this rule does not apply to organisms with partial breakpoints):

  • If the Observed interpretation is "Unknown" (i.e. there are no breakpoints defined for the organism-antibiotic combination in the active parameter set) AND the organism-antibiotic combination is defined to suppress the MIC, then display the tested antibiotic name, do not use the MIC in the expertise of the isolate (no biologic correction, no therapeutic correction, and no forcing rule), do not display the MIC in isolate view, and display a "blank" for the interpretation. (Cases removed from the truth table include:  2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10,13a, 18a, 34,36,37,45, 48,49,50,51,52)

    •  

    Developer and tester note:  In this case AST analysis generates an MIC.  However, the MIC is not used in biologic validation within the AES component.  In order to be compatible with VITEK 2 AIX, neither the MIC nor the Interpretation should be displayed.

     

    Reasons why an Observed interpretation can be "Unknown":

     

    • No breakpoints defined in the active parameter set for the organism-antibiotic combination.
    • Partial breakpoints defined (Unusual MIC) in the active parameter set for the organism-antibiotic combination.  In this case, the "blank" interpretation is highlighted and a pop-up alerts the customer.

     

    Reasons why a customer may have no MIC / test result and no Interpretation displayed for a tested antibiotic:

     

    • Organism-antibiotic combination is disclaimed in AST analysis.
    • Organism-antibiotic combination is claimed in AST analysis, but there are no breakpoints defined in the active parameter set.

     

    Reasons why a customer may see an antibiotic with an MIC, but a "blank" for an interpretation:

     

    • Unusual MIC detected ("blank" interpretation is highlighted on the screen)
    • Organism-antibiotic combination has no breakpoints defined in the active parameter set AND the MIC is not suppressed.
    • The Observed interpretation is a range (i.e. S/I, I/R, or S/R) and the Expertized interpretation value is the same as the Observed interpretation value.
    • Inconsistent KB, breakpoints are not synchronized with MIC distributions

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Backup Isolate Data with Syclop
requirement.description:
REN:ESPEC:769 Backup Isolate Data with Syclop [REN:PRD:XXX]

 

Primary actor: Syclop (Any VITEK 2 Systems authorized user)

 

Goal:   Backup user data.  User-data includes isolate information (including raw data) in the active workspace, information in the inactive workspace, and user customizations of the VITEK 2 System Software (general configuration settings, AES Config settings, SRF, BCI configurations for RS232 and BCI Net, etc.).  In essence, the entire Renaissance database is copied to a location known to Syclop.

 

Preconditions

  • Backup functionality is accessed from the Syclop application.  Navigation to the backup workspace from the start menu has been removed as of 05.01.
  • Syclop has been configured for backup
  • Syclop has access to write files to a storage location. Direct backup to a CD or DVD is not supported in release 05.01 of VITEK 2 Systems.  Customers can configure Syclop to backup to a USB device or local hard drive.  From these locations, a CD or DVD can be burned using the operating system.
  • Lab Technologist (local user) is logged in to Syclop and has requested a back up of data, or a scheduled “unattended” back up has been initiated.

 

Post conditions

 

  • User data saved to a location specified by the user.

 

Main Flow

 

 

  1. Use case starts when Syclop receives a request to back up user data.  The backup can be “attended” (initiated by a Syclop user; either Laboratory Technologist or Laboratory Supervisor) or “unattended” (scheduled, and initiated by the Syclop system). See Special Requirements for unattended backup tasks.  
  2. If an attended backup, user can select which installed component to backup from a list.  For VITEK 2 Systems, components include:
    1. V2C
    2. Syc (Syclop)
  3. If a user initiates the backup (i.e. attended), Syclop informs the Lab Tech that starting the backup process will impact other users by asking them to log off the VITEK 2 Systems application.  Syclop seeks confirmation to continue with the backup. If unattended backup, use case resumes at step 4 of the main flow. (ALT 5)
    1. Lab Tech acknowledges the message. Use case continues at step 4.
    2. If Lab Tech cancels, no action is taken and the use case ends.
  4. Syclop sends a message to VITEK 2 Systems to begin backup. Information includes:
    1. Who requested the backup (user ID or System)
    2. When the request was made (date / time)
  5. The VITEK 2 System validates that a backup can be performed and notifies Syclop. (ALT 2)
  6. The VITEK 2 Systems application determines that no remote users are logged in.      (ALT 1)
  7. The VITEK 2 Systems application performs data backup following these steps:   
    1. The VITEK 2 Systems application informs Syclop that the backup process is starting.
    2. The VITEK 2 Systems application prevents users from logging into the application.  Users are told that a backup is currently in process.
    3. The VITEK 2 Systems application makes the database available for backup.
    4. The VITEK 2 Systems application creates a replica of the entire VITEK 2 System database (isolate information, patient information, audit, user customizations, installed knowledge bases, etc.), inactive workspace along with the RS232 and BCI Net configurations for each defined link, and persists this in the VITEK 2 System in the Externalization Folder.
      1. Existing replica information, stored in the externalization folder by day of the week, is overwritten.
      2. Existing replica information is copied to the V2S backup directory used by Syclop
    5. The VITEK 2 Systems application notifies Syclop that the file creation was successful.  ALT (3)
  8. Syclop continues the backup process by copying the replica database, BCI Configurations (BCI-RS232 and BCI Net), and other selected components (i.e. Syclop database) to the location specified by the Laboratory Supervisor.  Locations include:
    1. USB Flash Drive
    2. Network drive
    3. Local hard drive (see Special Requirements)
    4. Note:  CD or DVD is not supported in release 05.01
  9. Syclop notifies the VITEK 2 Systems application that the backup was successful.  Information includes:  ALT (4)
    1. Who requested the backup (user ID or System)
    2. When the request was made (date / time)
  10. The VITEK 2 Systems application logs the event. Information includes:  
    1. Date/time of the backup
    2. Status of the backup (success or failure)
    3. User performing the backup (user ID if initiated by a user, or system if unattended)
    4. For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.
  11. VITEK 2 System makes the database accessible again to the application.
  12. Use case ends.

 

 

Alternate Flows / Variations

 

  1. REN:ESPEC:770 Remote users are logged in. [REN:PRD:700]
    1. Workstation notifies remote users that a backup is about to begin and that they should log off.
    2. Workstation waits for user to log off. If user doesn’t log off within the designated timeframe, the system will automatically logs the user off.
    3. Use case resumes at step 7 of main flow.

 

  • REN:ESPEC:772 Backup cannot begin. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. The VITEK 2 System is not able to do a backup for one of the following reasons:  
      1. EOD running
      2. DOU is running
      3. A backup is already running
      4. VITEK 2 Systems application is not available (Core is down, etc.)
    2. If attended, Syclop informs the Lab Tech that backup has failed to start.  A reason is supplied.  Once acknowledged, use case ends.
    3. If unattended, Syclop informs the Lab Tech that backup has failed to start.  A reason is supplied.  Use case ends.

     

     

     

  • REN:ESPEC:774 Backup file cannot be created. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. If unattended, the VITEK 2 System logs that the backup failed and the reason.  This information is captured as a VITEK 2 System alarm and is displayed to the next user to log into the VITEK 2 System.  Use case resumes at step 8 of the main flow.
    2. If attended, the VITEK 2 Systems application notifies Syclop that the backup file could not be created.  The Syclop application notifies the Lab Tech.  Lab tech acknowledges the message and the use case resumes at step 8 of the main flow.

     

  • REN:ESPEC:801 Syclop Backup failed. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. If attended, Syclop informs the Lab Tech that backup failed with reason.  Once acknowledged, Use case resumes at step 10 of the main flow.
    2. If unattended, Syclop notifies the VITEK 2 Systems application that the backup failed and includes a reason.  The VITEK 2 Systems application generates an alarm.  Use case resumes at step 10 of the main flow.
  • REN:ESPEC:804 Multiple backups requested by Lab Tech [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. Syclop displays a message to the Lab Tech that a backup is already in progress and that another backup should not be started.  Options include continue to with additional request or cancel.
    2. If the Lab Tech cancels, the additional request for a backup is canceled. Use case ends.
    3. If the Lab Tech elects to continue, Syclops generates another request for a backup.  Use case resumes at step 4 of the main flow.

     

    Special Requirements

    REN:ESPEC:781  Backup file created by the VITEK 2 Systems application is in the same format as release 04.01.  The backup file that Syclop creates includes the backup file created by the VITEK 2 Systems application and the backup file of the Syclop database, along with descriptor information. [REN:PRD:XXX]

     

    REN:ESPEC:797 Unattended (scheduled) backup tasks include the following. [REN:PRD:XXX]

     

    1. End of Day (see End Of Day Processing use case for details).  
    2. Database backup (this does not include Syclop backup.  This only includes creating a backup to the VITEK 2 Systems externalization folder)
    3. PC reboot (This function is executed by Syclop.  A PC reboot only occurs if Syclop executes EOD.  If EOD is executed manually from the bin folder, no reboot is executed.)

     

    REN:ESPEC:800  Syclop application maintains a rolling 7 day series of backups on the hard drive.  This functionality is comparable to the VITEK 2 Systems externalization folder. [REN:PRD:XXX]

     

     

    [See attachment TTRM791306206433440584.wmf]

    Figure 9:  ACT- Backup

requirement.summary: SCENARIO: Restore Isolate Data with Syclop
requirement.description:
REN:ESPEC:775 Restore Isolate Data with Syclop [REN:PRD:XXX]

 

Primary actor: Syclop (Laboratory Supervisor)

 

Goal:   Restore Isolate data from a stored file.  This operation is done to recover from a fatal application error (either software or hardware).  The purpose is to recover the VITEK 2 Systems application database (active workspace, inactive workspace, customer configurations, etc.), BCI configurations (BCI-RS232 and BCI Net), and Syclop database.

 

Preconditions

  • Syclop has access to stored files to complete restore
  • Lab Supervisor is logged into Syclop and has requested a restore of data.
  • Lab Supervisor has selected an isolate data backup to restore.

 

Post conditions

 

  • Backup data restored.

 

Main Flow

 

 

  1. Use case starts when Syclop receives a request to restore isolate data.
  2. Syclop presents a list of backup instances and the Lab Supervisor selects the database instance from which to restore.  For this use case, they have selected to restore a VITEK 2 Systems backup instance.
  3. Syclop informs the Lab Supervisor that starting the restore process for a VITEK 2 Systems backup instance will remove all current isolate data and impact other users by asking them to log off the VITEK 2 Systems application.  Syclop seeks confirmation to continue with the restore.
    1. Laboratory Supervisor acknowledges the message. Use case continues at step 4.
    2. If Laboratory Supervisor cancels, no action is taken and the use case ends.
  4. Syclop determines there is no version mismatch. (ALT 5)
  5. Syclop informs the VITEK 2 Systems that a restore has been requested.  Information includes:
    1. Who requested the backup (User ID)
    2. When the request was made (date and time)
  6. The VITEK 2 Systems validates that a restore can be performed and notifies Syclop. (ALT 3)
  7. Syclop copies the selected data backup to a location on the hard drive.
  8. Syclop verifies the VITEK 2 Systems Core Server is available. (ALT 4)
  9. The VITEK 2 Systems application ensures no remote users are logged in (ALT 1)
  10. The VITEK 2 Systems application finds the backup file (ALT 2)
  11. The VITEK 2 Systems application notifies Syclop that the restore can continue.
  12. The VITEK 2 Systems application ensures that remote users are not able to log into the application during a restore.
  13. Workstation performs data restore following these steps:   
    1. Syclop visually indicates that the workstation is ‘busy’ completing a restore.
    2. The VITEK 2 Systems application stops appropriate VITEK 2 Systems services (like Core, etc.)
    3. Workstation restores isolate data from backup location. This includes the VITEK 2 System database, BCI-RS232 and BCI Net configuration settings for each defined link, and information in the inactive workspace.  Based on the selection made in Syclop, other components can also be restored.
  14. Once complete, the VITEK 2 Systems application notifies Syclop that the restore is complete and was successful. (ALT 6)
  15. The VITEK 2 Systems application removes the intermediate backup file from the location specified by Syclop
  16. The VITEK 2 Systems application logs the event. Information includes:  
    1. Date/time of the restore
    2. Status of the restore (success or failure)
    3. User performing the restore (user ID)
    4. For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case.
  17. Syclop automatically reboots the Workstation, if a restore was attempted.
  18. Use case ends.

 

 

Alternate Flows / Variations

 

  1. REN:ESPEC:776 Remote users are logged in. [REN:PRD:700]
    1. The VITEK 2 Systems application notifies remote users that a restore is about to begin – please log off.
    2. The VITEK 2 Systems application waits for user to log off. If user doesn’t log off within the designated timeframe, the system will automatically log the user off.
    3. Use case resumes at step 10 of main flow.

 

  • REN:ESPEC:777 VITEK 2 Systems application could not locate the backup file [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. The VITEK 2 Systems application notifies Syclop that the backup file could not be located and that the restore has failed.
    2. Use case resumes at step 16 of main flow.

     

  • REN:ESPEC:779 Restore cannot begin. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. The VITEK 2 Systems application informs Syclop that restore cannot begin with reason. Reasons include:
      1. EOD running
      2. DOU running
      3. A restore is already running
    2. Use case resumes at step 16 of the main flow.

     

  • REN:ESPEC:782 VITEK 2 Systems Core server is not available. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. Syclop uses VITEK 2 Systems restore application to automatically restore the database.
    2. Syclop visually indicates that the workstation is ‘busy’ completing a restore.
    3. Use case resumes at step 9 of the Main Flow.

     

  • REN:ESPEC:792 Syclop detects a version mismatch. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. Syclop notifies the user of version mismatch.
    2. Syclop requests confirmation that user wants to proceed. If not confirmed, use case ends.
    3. User confirms the restore request.
    4. Syclop notifies VITEK 2 of the restore request.  Information includes:
      1. User ID requesting the restore
      2. Date and time of the request
    5. VITEK 2 System application checks versions.  
      1. If compatible, restore continues. Use case resumes at step 7 of main flow.
      2. If versions are not compatible, VITEK 2 notifies Syclop that restore cannot continue. (e.g.: cannot put 6.01 database on a 5.01 system, but can put a 4.02 database on a 4.01 system)
        1. Steps to take to resolve:
          1. Restore application software, version XXX in order to restore the selected database.
          2. Select a database, which is compatible with the installed version of the VITEK 2 Systems application.
          3. Use case resumes at step 12 of the main flow.
    6. Syclop notifies user that restore cannot continue.  There is a version mismatch error reported by the VITEK 2 Systems application.
    7. Use case resumes at step 16 of the main flow.

     

  • REN:ESPEC:801 Restore fails. [REN:PRD:XXX]
    1. The VITEK 2 Systems application informs Syclop that restore failed and includes a reason.
    2. Use case resumes at step 16 of the main flow.

     

    Special Requirements

     

     

    1. REN:ESPEC:783 Only members of the Laboratory Supervisor group are permitted to restore isolate information. [REN:PRD:XXX]

requirement.description:
REN:ESPEC:841 Synchronize Data with OBSERVA [REN:PRD:724] [REN:PRD:755]

Primary actor: Lab Supervisor, VITEK 2 Systems (Workstation)

 

Goal:   The Workstation can create and send a message to OBSERVA.  The purpose of this use case is to encode the message and send it on to OBSERVA. This action can be initiated at the request of the Lab Supervisor (Customize BCI Configuration use case) or successful completion of a Data Only Update.

 

Preconditions

  • Communication between OBSERVA and Workstation established.
  • “Port connected to OBSERVA” field in BCI Config (Upload tab) is enabled.

 

Post conditions

 

  • Synchronization message routed

 

Main Flow

 

  1. The use case begins when a Data Only Update completes successfully, or the Lab Supervisor navigates to the BCI Configuration Upload screen and indicates to the system to synchronize knowledgebase data with OBSERVA, if configured to do so. (ALT 1)
  2. If initiated by the Lab Supervisor, the Workstation will display a warning message including the following.  If initiated by Data Only Update, no warning will be displayed.
    1. This feature was created to support OBSERVA. Please ensure you are on the OBSERVA link before continuing.
    2. System will create a message to update the OBSERVA KB with information from VITEK 2 Systems knowledge base.
    3. Following the synchronization, please open the OBSERVA System Event Log and check for any issues detected with the data synchronization.
    4. Lab Supervisor can confirm or cancel. If cancelled, use case ends.
  3. Workstation creates the message to send to OBSERVA, which includes the following:

 

  1. Organisms (current list)
  2. Organism group association (current list – Organism taxon classification)
  3. Antibiotic families (current list)
  4. Antibiotics (current list)
  5. Antibiotic (antibiotic family association)
  6. bioART coded comments (current list; includes both predefined and custom)
  7. VITEK 2 Systems version that created the message
  8. Message version

 

  1. When the message is sent to OBSERVA, the Workstation logs the event with a message indicating that a user request to send synchronization message to OBSERVA. For details related to auditing, please see the Special Requirements section in Search Audit Trail use case
  2. Use case ends.

 

Alternate Flows / Variations

 

  1. REN:ESPEC:842 “Port connected to OBSERVA” is not enabled in BCI Config for any RS232 link. [REN:PRD:724]
    1. Lab Supervisor is unable to send a synchronization message to OBSERVA
    2. Use case ends.

 

Special Requirements  

None.

requirement.description:
REN:ESPEC:843 VILINK Message Transfer (Card Usage) [REN:PRD:731]

Primary actor: None (system use case)

 

Goal:   The Workstation can create and send a message containing card usage information to VILINK (via SysUtil).  The purpose of this use case is to encode the message and send it on to VILINK.

 

Preconditions

  • VILINK is installed.
  • VILINK Message Transfer option is enabled in General Configuration

 

Post conditions

 

  • Card usage message sent to VILINK via SysUtil

 

Main Flow

 

  1. The use case begins when the End of Day Process runs, creating the card usage message (see End Of Day Processing use case), if the VILINK Message Transfer option is enabled in General Configuration.
  2. The Workstation is rebooted or Core starts up, and the message is successfully sent from VITEK 2 Systems to SysUtil (see Boot Renaissance Workstation use case). (ALT 1)
  3. Lab Supervisor has the ability to “empty the queue” of messages. See Customize General Configuration use case for details.
  4. SysUtil successfully communicates the information to VILINK.  (ALT 2)
  5. Use case ends.

 

Alternate Flows / Variations

 

 

  1. REN:ESPEC:844 Card usage message was not successfully sent to SysUtil. [REN:PRD:731].
    1. Workstation generates an instrument alarm (type = warning) indicating that a card usage message could not be sent.  Alarm is presented in a visual and audible manner. This alarm is displayed to the next VITEK 2 Systems user to log in following the View and Maintain Alarms use case. Alarm indicates, “The workstation was unable to send (x) message(s) to VILINK”.
    2. Message is retained until a successful delivery to SysUtil is achieved.
    3. Use case resumes at step 1 of the Main Flow when the next End of Day process runs.
  2. REN:ESPEC:845 SysUtil was unable to communicate with VILINK. [REN:PRD:XXX].

 

  1. SysUtil informs the Workstation that it encountered a communication problem with VILINK.
  2. Workstation generates an instrument alarm (type = warning) indicating that a communication problem exists between SysUtil and VILINK.  Alarm is presented in a visual and audible manner. This alarm is displayed to the next VITEK 2 Systems user to log in following the View and Maintain Alarms use case. Alarm indicates, “SysUtil was unable to communicate with VILINK”.
  3. Message is retained until a successful delivery to VILINK is achieved.
  4. Use case resumes at step 1 of the Main Flow when the next End of Day process runs.

 

Special Requirements  

 

  1. REN:ESPEC:846 If necessary, the Lab Supervisor can manage (empty) the queue (see Customize General Configuration use case). [REN:PRD:760]
